question: What is the definition of 'automated employment decision tool'?
reference_answer: The term 'automated employment decision tool' means any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. It does not include tools that do not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making processes and that do not materially impact natural persons.

Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other

ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.

to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code. 
 
Employment Agency. “Employment agency” means “Employment agency” as defined by 6 RCNY § 5-
249.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

agent_answer: The purpose of a bias audit for automated employment decision tools is to evaluate the tool's potential disparate impact on individuals based on race/ethnicity and sex categories. The audit assesses whether the tool's selection rates for different categories are significantly different from the most selected category. By conducting a bias audit, employers and employment agencies can identify and address any potential biases or discriminatory effects of the tool, ensuring fair and equitable employment decisions. The results of the bias audit must be publicly available to promote transparency and accountability.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation that aligns with the ground truth. It correctly identifies the purpose of a bias audit as assessing disparate impact on individuals based on specific categories and mentions the importance of transparency and accountability.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly addresses the purpose of a bias audit and covers multiple relevant aspects, but it includes some unnecessary details about public availability that are not central to the query.

question: What are the requirements for the published results of the bias audit?
reference_answer: The requirements for the published results of the required bias audit are clarified in the new rules. These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category that is required to be reported to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to determine an impact ratio.
reference_context:
Document 9: 4 
 
iii. 
at any point during the bias audit, has a direct financial interest or a material indirect 
financial interest in an employer or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to 
use the  AEDT or in a vendor that developed or distributed the AEDT. 
 
Impact Ratio. “Impact ratio” means either (1) the selection rate for a category divided by the selection 
rate of the most selected category or (2) the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the 
highest scoring category.  
 
 
 
    _________selection rate for a category________  
Impact Ratio =        selection rate of the most selected category  
 
OR 
 
  
 
     ______scoring rate for a category__________  
Impact Ratio =        scoring rate of the highest scoring category 
 
 
Machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence. “Machine learning, 
statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence” means a group of mathematical, computer-
based techniques:  
i. 
that generate a prediction, meaning an expected outcome for an observation, such as an 
assessment of a candidate’s fit or likelihood of success, or that generate a classification, 
meaning an assignment of an observation to a group, such as categorizations based on 
skill sets or aptitude; and  
ii. 
for which a computer at least in part identifies the inputs, the relative importance placed 
on those inputs, and, if applicable, other parameters for the models in order to improve 
the accuracy of the prediction or classification. 
 
Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example.

Document 15: 7 
 
(3) Calculate the impact ratio for each category;  
(4) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision 
separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (i.e., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates); and  
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
(d) Notwithstanding the requirements of paragraphs (2) and (3) of subdivision (b) and paragraphs (3) and 
(4) of subdivision (c), an independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of 
the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. Where such a 
category is excluded, the summary of results must include the independent auditor’s justification for the 
exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded 
category.  
 
Example: An employer uses an AEDT to score applicants for “culture fit.” To do so, the employer must 
ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than a year before the use of the AEDT.

Document 10: Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example. If 100 Hispanic women apply for a position and 40 are selected for an interview after use of an 
AEDT, the selection rate for Hispanic women is 40/100 or 40%.  
 
Simplified output. “Simplified output” means a prediction or classification as specified in the definition 
for “machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence.” A simplified output 
may take the form of a score (e.g., rating a candidate’s estimated technical skills), tag or categorization 
(e.g., categorizing a candidate’s resume based on key words, assigning a skill or trait to a candidate), 
recommendation (e.g., whether a candidate should be given an interview), or ranking (e.g., arranging a 
list of candidates based on how well their cover letters match the job description). It does not refer to the 
output from analytical tools that translate or transcribe existing text, e.g., convert a resume from a PDF 
or transcribe a video or audio interview.

Document 5: These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law. 
 
Specifically, these new rules will: 
 
Define terms; 
 
Clarify the requirements for a bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for the published results of the required bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for notices that employers and employment agencies must provide to employees 
and candidates for employment; and  
 
Clarify other obligations for the employer or employment agency.  
 
The Department initially proposed a version of these rules in September 2022. The Department received 
comments from the public, including from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and 
advocacy organizations. Various issues raised in the comments led to a second version of the proposed rules, 
published in December 2022. Those changes included:  
 
Modifying the definition of AEDT to ensure greater focus; 
 
Clarifying that an “independent auditor” may not be employed or have a financial interest in an employer 
or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to use an AEDT or in a vendor that developed or 
distributed the AEDT; 
 
Revising the required calculation to be performed where an AEDT scores candidates;
metadata: {'question_type': 'simple', 'seed_document_id': 9, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': None, 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The requirements for the published results of the bias audit are as follows:

1. The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT must be made publicly available on the employment section of the employer or employment agency's website in a clear and conspicuous manner.

2. A summary of the results of the bias audit must be provided, which should include the following information:
   a. The source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit.
   b. The number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that fall within an unknown category.
   c. The number of applicants or candidates.
   d. The selection or scoring rates, as applicable.
   e. The impact ratios for all categories.

3. The distribution date of the AEDT must also be provided.

4. The requirements can be met by providing an active hyperlink to a website containing the required summary of results and distribution date, as long as the link is clearly identified as a link to the results of the bias audit.

5. The employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for at least 6 months after its latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed list of requirements for publishing the results of a bias audit, but it does not specifically address the calculation of selection rates and impact ratios for each race/ethnicity and sex category as required by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). The ground truth focuses on these specific calculations and comparisons, which are not mentioned in the agent's response.
reason_method2: The generated answer provides a detailed list of requirements for the bias audit but does not address the specific requirement to calculate selection rates for each race/ethnicity and sex category, which is a key component of the user query.

question: Where can a proceeding to recover a civil penalty authorized by this subchapter be returnable to?
reference_answer: A proceeding to recover a civil penalty authorized by this subchapter can be returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
reference_context:
Document 3: d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-873 Enforcement.
The corporation counsel or such other persons designated by the corporation counsel on behalf of the department may initiate in any court of competent
jurisdiction any action or proceeding that may be appropriate or necessary for correction of any violation issued pursuant this subchapter, including
mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-874 Construction.
The provisions of this subchapter shall not be construed to limit any right of any candidate or employee for an employment decision to bring a civil action
in any court of competent jurisdiction, or to limit the authority of the commission on human rights to enforce the provisions of title 8, in accordance with
law.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)

mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-874 Construction.
The provisions of this subchapter shall not be construed to limit any right of any candidate or employee for an employment decision to bring a civil action
in any court of competent jurisdiction, or to limit the authority of the commission on human rights to enforce the provisions of title 8, in accordance with
law.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)

question: What are the specific calculations and requirements for conducting a bias audit of an AEDT, including the categories that need to be considered and the conditions under which historical data or test data can be used?
reference_answer: The minimum requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT are: calculating the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, including sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race; performing these calculations for each group if the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups; and indicating the number of individuals not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category.
reference_context:
Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.
metadata: {'question_type': 'complex', 'seed_document_id': 11, 'topic': 'Metrics/Data', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': None, 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
To conduct a bias audit of an AEDT (Automated Employment Decision Tool), the following calculations and requirements must be considered:

1. Historical Data: The bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT. This data can be from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit using historical data from other employers or agencies only if they provided their own historical data to the independent auditor or if they have never used the AEDT.

2. Test Data: If there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit using test data. The summary of results must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data was generated and obtained.

3. Selection Rate Calculation: The bias audit must calculate the selection rate for each category. This includes calculating the selection rate for different sex categories (e.g., male candidates vs. female candidates), race/ethnicity categories (e.g., Hispanic or Latino candidates vs. Black or African American candidates), and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race.

4. Impact Ratio Calculation: The bias audit must calculate the impact ratio for each category. This includes calculating the impact ratio for different sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories. The impact ratio measures the impact of the AEDT on the selection or scoring of candidates in each category.

5. Group Calculations: If the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles), the bias audit must perform the calculations mentioned above for each group.

6. Unknown Category: The bias audit must indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that are not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category.

7. Scoring Rate Calculation: If the AEDT scores candidates, the bias audit must calculate the median score for the full sample of applicants. It must also calculate the scoring rate for individuals in each category, including sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories.

8. Justification for Exclusion: An independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of the data used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. In such cases, the summary of results must include the auditor's justification for the exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded category.

These calculations and requirements ensure that the bias audit comprehensively assesses the impact of the AEDT on different categories and helps identify any potential biases in the tool's decision-making process.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer is overly detailed and includes additional information not specified in the ground truth. The ground truth focuses on the minimum requirements: calculating selection rate and impact ratio for each category, performing these calculations for each group if applicable, and indicating the number of individuals in unknown categories. The agent's answer, while informative, goes beyond these minimum requirements.
reason_method2: The generated answer covers all components of the user query and provides detailed information, but it includes some minor inaccuracies regarding the conditions for using historical data.

question: What is the definition of 'Impact Ratio' and how is it calculated in relation to the selection rate or scoring rate of different categories?
reference_answer: The 'Impact Ratio' can be calculated either as the selection rate for a category divided by the selection rate of the most selected category, or as the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the highest scoring category.
reference_context:
Document 10: Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example. If 100 Hispanic women apply for a position and 40 are selected for an interview after use of an 
AEDT, the selection rate for Hispanic women is 40/100 or 40%.  
 
Simplified output. “Simplified output” means a prediction or classification as specified in the definition 
for “machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence.” A simplified output 
may take the form of a score (e.g., rating a candidate’s estimated technical skills), tag or categorization 
(e.g., categorizing a candidate’s resume based on key words, assigning a skill or trait to a candidate), 
recommendation (e.g., whether a candidate should be given an interview), or ranking (e.g., arranging a 
list of candidates based on how well their cover letters match the job description). It does not refer to the 
output from analytical tools that translate or transcribe existing text, e.g., convert a resume from a PDF 
or transcribe a video or audio interview.

for which a computer at least in part identifies the inputs, the relative importance placed

metadata: {'question_type': 'complex', 'seed_document_id': 10, 'topic': 'Definitions', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': None, 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The impact ratio is a measure used in the bias audit of an automated employment decision tool (AEDT) to assess the impact of the tool on different categories, such as sex and race/ethnicity. It is calculated by comparing the selection rate or scoring rate of a specific category to the selection rate or scoring rate of the most selected category.

In the context of selection rate, the impact ratio is calculated by dividing the selection rate of a specific category by the selection rate of the most selected category. For example, if the selection rate for male candidates is 48% and the selection rate for female candidates is 47%, the impact ratio for female candidates would be 0.979 (47% divided by 48%).

In the context of scoring rate, the impact ratio is calculated by dividing the scoring rate of a specific category by the scoring rate of the most selected category. For example, if the scoring rate for Hispanic or Latino candidates is 64.2% and the scoring rate for White (Not Hispanic or Latino) candidates is 37.5%, the impact ratio for Hispanic or Latino candidates would be 1.71 (64.2% divided by 37.5%).

The impact ratio helps identify any disparities or biases in the selection or scoring process of the AEDT. A ratio of 1.00 indicates no impact or disparity, while a ratio below 1.00 indicates a lower selection or scoring rate compared to the most selected category, and a ratio above 1.00 indicates a higher selection or scoring rate compared to the most selected category.

metadata: {'question_type': 'complex', 'seed_document_id': 18, 'topic': 'Metrics/Data', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': None, 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
In the context of conducting a bias audit for an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT), historical data and test data have different meanings and purposes.

Historical data refers to data that is collected during an employer or employment agency's actual use of the AEDT to assess candidates for employment or employees for promotion. It represents real-world data that reflects the outcomes and decisions made by the AEDT in the past. Historical data is used to assess the presence of bias in the AEDT's decision-making process.

On the other hand, test data refers to data that is specifically used for conducting a bias audit when there is insufficient historical data available. Test data is not collected from actual usage of the AEDT but is generated or obtained separately for the purpose of evaluating the AEDT's performance. It is used when there is a need to conduct a statistically significant bias audit but there is not enough historical data to do so.

In summary, historical data is the actual data collected during the use of the AEDT, while test data is generated or obtained specifically for the bias audit when there is a lack of sufficient historical data.

consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.

(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

agent_answer:
The requirements for conducting a bias audit for an AEDT are outlined in section 5-301 of the Chapter. An employer or employment agency must conduct a bias audit of the AEDT at least once every year. The bias audit must include the following:

1. Calculation of the selection rate for each category.
2. Calculation of the impact ratio for each category.
3. Separate calculation of the impact of the AEDT on sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race.
4. If the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups, the calculations must be performed for each group.
5. Indication of the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT who are not included in the calculations due to an unknown category.

Additionally, if the AEDT scores candidates, the bias audit must also include the following:

1. Calculation of the median score for the full sample of applicants.
2. Calculation of the scoring rate for individuals in each category.
3. Calculation of the impact ratio for each category.
4. Separate calculation of the impact of the AEDT on sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race.
5. Indication of the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT who are not included in the calculations due to an unknown category.

In cases where there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. However, the summary of results of the bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was generated and obtained.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer is overly detailed and includes specific procedural steps that are not mentioned in the ground truth. The ground truth focuses on the purpose of the bias audit, which is to calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for different categories to ensure the AEDT is not biased. The agent's answer, while informative, does not align with the concise explanation provided in the ground truth.
reason_method2: The generated answer comprehensively addresses all components of the user query, providing detailed requirements for conducting a bias audit for an AEDT and correctly explaining the use of test data when historical data is insufficient.

question: According to the document, what is the definition of 'Candidate for Employment'?
reference_answer: A 'Candidate for Employment' refers to a person who has applied for a specific employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the employer or employment agency.
reference_context:
Document 4: 1 
 
New York City Department of Consumer and Worker Protection 
 
Notice of Adoption of Final Rule 
 
Pursuant to the authority vested in the Commissioner of the Department of Consumer and Worker Protection by 
Sections 1043 and 2203(f) of the New York City Charter and Section 20-104(b) of the New York City 
Administrative Code, and in accordance with the requirements of Section 1043 of the New York City Charter, 
the Department amends Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York.  
 
An initial version of this rule was proposed and published on September 23, 2022. A public hearing was held on 
November 4, 2022, and comments regarding the rule were received. DCWP proposed a second version of this 
rule on December 23, 2022. A public hearing was held on January 23, 2023, and comments regarding the rule 
were received.  
 
Statement of Basis and Purpose 
 
The Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (“DCWP” or “Department”) is adding rules to implement 
new legislation regarding automated employment decision tools (“AEDT”). Local Law 144 of 2021 prohibits 
employers and employment agencies from using an automated employment decision tool unless the tool has 
been subject to a bias audit within one year of the use of the tool, information about the bias audit is publicly 
available, and certain notices have been provided to employees or job candidates.   
 
These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law.

Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code. 
 
Employment Agency. “Employment agency” means “Employment agency” as defined by 6 RCNY § 5-
249.  
 
Historical data.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

question: What are the steps and criteria for conducting a bias audit of an AEDT, including the calculation of impact ratios for different categories such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories?
reference_answer: A bias audit of an AEDT must, at a minimum, calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, including sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race. The audit must also indicate the number of individuals excluded from the calculations due to falling within an unknown category.

ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino

Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

agent_answer:
The steps and criteria for conducting a bias audit of an AEDT, including the calculation of impact ratios for different categories, are outlined in the rules. Here is a summary of the steps and criteria:

1. Calculate the selection rate for each category: The bias audit must calculate the selection rate for each category, such as sex and race/ethnicity. This involves determining the number of applicants in each category and the number of applicants selected.

2. Calculate the impact ratio for each category: The bias audit must calculate the impact ratio for each category. The impact ratio compares the selection rate of each category to the selection rate of the most selected category. This helps determine if there are disparities in the selection process based on different categories.

3. Separate calculations for sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories: The calculations for selection rate and impact ratio must be performed separately for sex categories (e.g., male vs. female), race/ethnicity categories (e.g., Hispanic or Latino vs. Black or African American), and intersectional categories that combine sex, ethnicity, and race.

4. Perform calculations for each group (if applicable): If the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles), the calculations for selection rate and impact ratio must be performed for each group.

5. Indicate the number of individuals in unknown categories: The bias audit must indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that are not included in the calculations because their category (sex or race/ethnicity) is unknown.

Additionally, the rules allow for the exclusion of categories that represent less than 2% of the data being used for the bias audit from the calculations of impact ratio. However, the summary of results must include the justification for the exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and the scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded category.

These steps and criteria ensure that the bias audit assesses the impact of the AEDT on different categories and helps identify any potential biases in the selection process.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of the steps and criteria for conducting a bias audit of an AEDT, including the calculation of impact ratios for different categories such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. It aligns with the ground truth, which requires the calculation of selection rates and impact ratios for each category and the indication of individuals excluded due to unknown categories.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly outlines the steps and criteria for conducting a bias audit of an AEDT and addresses all components of the user query, with only minor errors regarding the completeness of the explanation.

question: What information does an employer or employment agency need to make publicly available before using an AEDT?
reference_answer: Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency must make publicly available on the employment section of their website the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. The summary should include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that fall within an unknown category, and the number of applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios for all categories. Additionally, the distribution date of the AEDT must also be provided.

§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall

containing the required summary of results and distribution date, provided that the link is clearly identified 
as a link to results of the bias audit. 
(c) An employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for 
at least 6 months after its latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.   
 
§ 5-304 Notice to Candidates and Employees.  
(a) The notice required by § 20-871(b)(1) of the Code must include instructions for how an individual can 
request an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation under other laws, if 
available. Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT.

(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT. 
(c) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to an employee being considered for promotion who resides in the city by doing any of the 
following: 
(1) Provide notice in a written policy or procedure that is provided to employees at least 10 
business days before use of an AEDT;

(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT.  
(d) To comply with § 20-871(b)(3) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must: 
(1) Provide information on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous 
manner about its AEDT data retention policy, the type of data collected for the AEDT, and the 
source of the data; 
(2) Post instructions on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
for how to make a written request for such information, and if a written request is received, 
provide such information within 30 days; and 
(3) Provide an explanation to a candidate for employment or employee being considered for 
promotion why disclosure of such information would violate local, state, or federal law, or 
interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

agent_answer:
Before using an AEDT (Automated Employment Decision Tool), an employer or employment agency in New York City must make the following information publicly available on the employment section of their website:

1. The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. This summary should include:
   - The source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit.
   - The number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that fall within an unknown category.
   - The number of applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios for all categories.

2. The distribution date of the AEDT.

The requirements can also be met by providing an active hyperlink to a website containing the required summary of results and distribution date, as long as the link is clearly identified as a link to the results of the bias audit.

Additionally, the employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for at least 6 months after the latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.

question: To which tribunals or agencies can a proceeding to recover a civil penalty authorized by this subchapter be brought?
reference_answer: A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter can be returned to any tribunal established within the office of administrative trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.

question: What are the specific calculations that must be performed in a bias audit of an AEDT for candidate selection or promotion, and what are the categories that these calculations must be separately performed for?
reference_answer: The minimum requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT include calculating the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, including sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories. The calculations should also be performed for each group if the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups. Additionally, the audit should indicate the number of individuals not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category.
reference_context:
Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

agent_answer:
In a bias audit of an AEDT for candidate selection or promotion, the following calculations must be performed:

1. Selection Rate: Calculate the selection rate for each category. This involves dividing the number of individuals in a category who were selected to move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by the total number of individuals in that category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.

2. Impact Ratio: Calculate the impact ratio for each category. The impact ratio is calculated by dividing the selection rate for a category by the selection rate of the most selected category. This ratio measures the relative impact of the AEDT on different categories.

3. Intersectional Categories: Calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for intersectional categories, which involve combinations of sex, ethnicity, and race. For example, the impact ratio can be calculated for Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American female candidates.

4. Group Categories: If the AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles), the calculations in paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 must be performed for each group.

Additionally, the calculations must be separately performed for the following categories:

- Sex Categories: Calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for male candidates vs. female candidates.
- Race/Ethnicity Categories: Calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for different racial and ethnic categories, such as Hispanic or Latino, White (Not Hispanic or Latino), Black or African American (Not Hispanic or Latino), Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander (Not Hispanic or Latino), Asian (Not Hispanic or Latino), Native American or Alaska Native (Not Hispanic or Latino), and Two or More Races (Not Hispanic or Latino).

It is important to note that these calculations must be performed for each category separately to assess the impact of the AEDT on different demographic groups.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of the calculations required for a bias audit of an AEDT, including selection rate, impact ratio, and the need to perform these calculations for sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories. It also mentions the need to perform these calculations for each group if the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups. Although the agent's answer is more detailed, it aligns with the ground truth requirements.
reason_method2: The generated answer comprehensively covers all components of the user query, accurately detailing the necessary calculations and categories for a bias audit of an AEDT without any errors.

agent_answer:
In a bias audit of an AEDT, the following calculations must be performed for each category:

1. Selection Rate: Calculate the selection rate for each category. This involves determining the percentage of applicants selected for further consideration or advancement in the hiring process within each category.

2. Impact Ratio: Calculate the impact ratio for each category. This involves comparing the selection rate of one category to the selection rate of a reference category (usually the category with the highest selection rate). The impact ratio is calculated by dividing the selection rate of the category being analyzed by the selection rate of the reference category.

3. Intersectional Categories: If applicable, calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for intersectional categories. This involves analyzing the impact of the AEDT on candidates who fall into multiple categories, such as sex, ethnicity, and race.

4. Group Analysis: If the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups, perform the calculations mentioned above for each group. This ensures that the impact of the AEDT is assessed within each group separately.

Additionally, the bias audit should indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT who are not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category. This information helps provide a comprehensive understanding of the audit results.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer is overly detailed and includes additional steps that are not specified in the ground truth. The ground truth only requires the calculation of the selection rate and impact ratio for each category.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly identifies the necessary calculations for a bias audit of an AEDT, including selection rate and impact ratio, while providing additional relevant details, though it slightly exceeds the specific requirements of the query.

question: What is the role of the AEDT in conducting bias audits and what are the requirements for using historical data in the audit?
reference_answer: The AEDT (Applicant Employment Data Template) is used to conduct bias audits. It provides historical data that is used to assess bias in hiring practices. Employers and employment agencies can rely on a bias audit that uses the historical data of the AEDT, either from their own use or from other employers or agencies, if certain conditions are met. If insufficient historical data is available, test data can be used for a bias audit.

these individuals was not included in the calculations above. 
§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

agent_answer:
The AEDT (Artificial Intelligence Employment Decision Tools) plays a central role in conducting bias audits. It is used by employers and employment agencies to select candidates for employment or promotion. The bias audit is conducted to ensure that the AEDT does not have a discriminatory impact on protected categories such as sex, race, and ethnicity.

When conducting a bias audit, the use of historical data is required. The historical data used should be from the AEDT's previous use by one or more employers or employment agencies. However, an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from other employers or agencies only if they have provided their own historical data to the independent auditor or if they have never used the AEDT before.

In cases where there is insufficient historical data available, the employer or employment agency may use test data for the bias audit. However, the summary of results must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data was generated and obtained.

Overall, the use of historical data is essential in conducting bias audits for AEDTs, but there are provisions for using test data in certain circumstances.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)

employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.

mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.

agent_answer:
An automated employment decision tool is defined as any computational process that uses machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to issue simplified output, such as a score, classification, or recommendation. This tool is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making in employment decisions that impact individuals. However, it does not include tools that do not automate or substantially assist discretionary decision-making processes and do not materially impact individuals, such as junk email filters, firewalls, antivirus software, calculators, spreadsheets, databases, data sets, or other compilations of data.

In the city, there are requirements for the use of automated employment decision tools in screening candidates or employees for employment decisions. These requirements are as follows:

1. Bias Audit: The tool must have undergone a bias audit conducted within one year prior to its use. The bias audit is an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor, which includes testing the tool for its disparate impact on individuals of any component category required to be reported by employers under federal regulations.

2. Public Availability of Audit Results: A summary of the most recent bias audit results of the tool, along with the distribution date of the tool to which the audit applies, must be made publicly available on the employer or employment agency's website before the tool is used.

3. Notices to Employees/Candidates: Employers or employment agencies using an automated employment decision tool must provide certain notices to employees or candidates who reside in the city. These notices include:

   a. Notification of Tool Use: The employer or agency must inform the employee or candidate, at least ten business days before the tool's use, that an automated employment decision tool will be used in assessing or evaluating them. The notice should also allow the candidate to request an alternative selection process or accommodation.

   b. Job Qualifications and Characteristics: The employer or agency must disclose, at least ten business days before the tool's use, the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in assessing the candidate or employee.

   c. Data Information: If not already disclosed on the employer or agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the tool, the source of such data, and the employer or agency's data retention policy must be made available upon written request by a candidate or employee. This information should be provided within 30 days of the written request, except where disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer includes the correct definition of an automated employment decision tool but also adds extensive information about the requirements for its use in the city, which was not part of the ground truth answer. The ground truth answer only required the definition of the tool.
reason_method2: The generated answer accurately defines an automated employment decision tool and comprehensively outlines the requirements for its use in the city, aligning closely with the reference answer without any factual errors.

agent_answer:
The AEDT (Automated Employment Decision Tool) is the tool or software used by an employer or employment agency to make employment-related decisions, such as selecting candidates for employment or employees for promotion. In the context of a bias audit, the AEDT is the subject of evaluation to determine if it has any biases or discriminatory effects.

The bias audit is conducted to assess the impact of the AEDT on different categories of candidates or employees, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. The audit calculates selection rates, impact ratios, and scoring rates to identify any disparities or biases in the AEDT's outcomes for different categories.

Under certain circumstances, an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit using test data instead of historical data. This is allowed when there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. The summary of results of the bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was generated and obtained.

It's important to note that an employer or employment agency can also rely on a bias audit using historical data from other employers or employment agencies if they have not used the AEDT before or if they provided their own historical data to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit. However, an employer or employment agency cannot rely on a bias audit using test data if they have sufficient historical data available.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer incorrectly defines AEDT as an Automated Employment Decision Tool, while the ground truth defines AEDT as the Applicant Employment Data Template used for providing historical data for bias audits. The agent's answer also includes additional information not present in the ground truth.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly explains the role of the AEDT in a bias audit and the circumstances under which an employer can rely on test data, but it introduces some minor inaccuracies regarding the definition of AEDT and its application.

question: What are the specific calculations and requirements that must be performed during a bias audit of an AEDT for selection rates, impact ratios, and categories of sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectionality?
reference_answer: A bias audit of an AEDT must, at a minimum, calculate the selection rate for each category, calculate the impact ratio for each category, ensure that the calculations separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories, and indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that are not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category.
reference_context:
Document 5: These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law. 
 
Specifically, these new rules will: 
 
Define terms; 
 
Clarify the requirements for a bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for the published results of the required bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for notices that employers and employment agencies must provide to employees 
and candidates for employment; and  
 
Clarify other obligations for the employer or employment agency.  
 
The Department initially proposed a version of these rules in September 2022. The Department received 
comments from the public, including from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and 
advocacy organizations. Various issues raised in the comments led to a second version of the proposed rules, 
published in December 2022. Those changes included:  
 
Modifying the definition of AEDT to ensure greater focus; 
 
Clarifying that an “independent auditor” may not be employed or have a financial interest in an employer 
or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to use an AEDT or in a vendor that developed or 
distributed the AEDT; 
 
Revising the required calculation to be performed where an AEDT scores candidates;

Document 6: 2 
 
 
Clarifying that the required “impact ratio” must be calculated separately to compare sex categories, 
race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories; 
 
Clarifying the types of data that may be used to conduct a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying that multiple employers using the same AEDT may rely on the same bias audit so long as they 
provide historical data, if available, for the independent auditor to consider in such bias audit; and 
 
Clarifying that an AEDT may not be used if its most recent bias audit is more than a year old; 
 
The Department received comments about the second version of the proposed rule from the public, including 
from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and advocacy organizations. Various 
issues raised in the comments resulted in changes that are present in these final rules. These changes include: 
 
Modifying the definition of “machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence” 
to expand its scope; 
 
Adding a requirement that the bias audit indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are 
not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category, and requiring that number 
be included in the summary of results; 
 
Allowing an independent auditor to exclude a category that comprises less than 2% of the data being 
used for the bias audit from the calculations of impact ratio; 
 
Clarifying the examples of a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted using the 
historical data of other employers or employment agencies; 
 
Providing examples of when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted with 
historical data, test data, or historical data from other employers and employment agencies; 
 
Clarifying that the number of applicants in a category and scoring rate of a category, if applicable, must 
be included in the summary of results. 
 
New material is underlined. 
[Deleted material is in brackets.] 
 
“Shall” and “must” denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this 
department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.
