question: What are the requirements for a bias audit and what is test data in the context of a bias audit?
reference_answer: The requirements for a bias audit include calculating the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category and comparing the selection rates to determine an impact ratio. Test data in the context of a bias audit refers to data used to conduct the audit that is not historical data.
reference_context:
Document 5: These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law. 
 
Specifically, these new rules will: 
 
Define terms; 
 
Clarify the requirements for a bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for the published results of the required bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for notices that employers and employment agencies must provide to employees 
and candidates for employment; and  
 
Clarify other obligations for the employer or employment agency.  
 
The Department initially proposed a version of these rules in September 2022. The Department received 
comments from the public, including from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and 
advocacy organizations. Various issues raised in the comments led to a second version of the proposed rules, 
published in December 2022. Those changes included:  
 
Modifying the definition of AEDT to ensure greater focus; 
 
Clarifying that an “independent auditor” may not be employed or have a financial interest in an employer 
or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to use an AEDT or in a vendor that developed or 
distributed the AEDT; 
 
Revising the required calculation to be performed where an AEDT scores candidates;

Document 6: 2 
 
 
Clarifying that the required “impact ratio” must be calculated separately to compare sex categories, 
race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories; 
 
Clarifying the types of data that may be used to conduct a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying that multiple employers using the same AEDT may rely on the same bias audit so long as they 
provide historical data, if available, for the independent auditor to consider in such bias audit; and 
 
Clarifying that an AEDT may not be used if its most recent bias audit is more than a year old; 
 
The Department received comments about the second version of the proposed rule from the public, including 
from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and advocacy organizations. Various 
issues raised in the comments resulted in changes that are present in these final rules. These changes include: 
 
Modifying the definition of “machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence” 
to expand its scope; 
 
Adding a requirement that the bias audit indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are 
not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category, and requiring that number 
be included in the summary of results; 
 
Allowing an independent auditor to exclude a category that comprises less than 2% of the data being 
used for the bias audit from the calculations of impact ratio; 
 
Clarifying the examples of a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted using the 
historical data of other employers or employment agencies; 
 
Providing examples of when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted with 
historical data, test data, or historical data from other employers and employment agencies; 
 
Clarifying that the number of applicants in a category and scoring rate of a category, if applicable, must 
be included in the summary of results. 
 
New material is underlined. 
[Deleted material is in brackets.] 
 
“Shall” and “must” denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this 
department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

Document 15: 7 
 
(3) Calculate the impact ratio for each category;  
(4) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision 
separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (i.e., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates); and  
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
(d) Notwithstanding the requirements of paragraphs (2) and (3) of subdivision (b) and paragraphs (3) and 
(4) of subdivision (c), an independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of 
the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. Where such a 
category is excluded, the summary of results must include the independent auditor’s justification for the 
exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded 
category.  
 
Example: An employer uses an AEDT to score applicants for “culture fit.” To do so, the employer must 
ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than a year before the use of the AEDT.

agent_answer:
In the context of a bias audit, the requirements and definitions are as follows:

1. Historical Data: A bias audit must use historical data of the Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) being audited. This historical data can be from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency can only rely on a bias audit using historical data from other employers or agencies if they provided their own historical data to the independent auditor or if they have never used the AEDT.

2. Test Data: If there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. Test data is data specifically generated and obtained for the purpose of the bias audit. If test data is used, the summary of the bias audit results must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data was generated and obtained.

In summary, a bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT, but in certain circumstances, an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit using historical data from other entities or a bias audit using test data if there is a lack of sufficient historical data.

reason_method2: The generated answer contains significant inaccuracies regarding the requirements for a bias audit, particularly by emphasizing historical data instead of the necessary calculations and comparisons, while it does address the concept of test data correctly.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency

employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT.

agent_answer:
The definition of 'test data' is data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. In other words, it is data that is not collected during an employer or employment agency's actual use of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) to assess candidates for employment or employees for promotion.

The requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT are as follows:

1. Historical Data: A bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT. This data can be from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency can only rely on a bias audit that uses the historical data of other employers or employment agencies if they provided their own historical data to the independent auditor or if they have never used the AEDT.

2. Test Data: If there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. The summary of results of the bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was generated and obtained.

It is important to note that an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit conducted using test data only if there is a valid reason for not using historical data. Additionally, an employer or employment agency cannot rely on a bias audit conducted using test data if they have statistically significant historical data available.

agent_answer:
Test data, as defined in the context provided, refers to data that is used in a bias audit when there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant analysis. It is data that is generated and obtained specifically for the purpose of conducting the bias audit.

An employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit that uses test data in the following circumstances:

1. Insufficient Historical Data: When there is a lack of historical data from the employer or employment agency's use of the automated employment decision tool (AEDT), they can use a bias audit that utilizes test data.

2. Explanation and Description: If test data is used in the bias audit, the summary of the audit results must explain why historical data was not available and describe how the test data was generated and obtained.

In summary, an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit that uses test data when there is a lack of historical data for a statistically significant analysis of the AEDT's bias impact.

question: What methods can an employer or employment agency use to provide notice to a candidate for employment, and what information must they make publicly available before the use of an AEDT?
reference_answer: An employer or employment agency can provide notice to a candidate for employment by providing notice on the employment section of its website, in a job posting, or via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT. They must also make publicly available the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, as well as the distribution date of the AEDT.
reference_context:
Document 21: Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT. 
(c) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to an employee being considered for promotion who resides in the city by doing any of the 
following: 
(1) Provide notice in a written policy or procedure that is provided to employees at least 10 
business days before use of an AEDT;

Document 22: 10 
 
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT.  
(d) To comply with § 20-871(b)(3) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must: 
(1) Provide information on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous 
manner about its AEDT data retention policy, the type of data collected for the AEDT, and the 
source of the data; 
(2) Post instructions on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
for how to make a written request for such information, and if a written request is received, 
provide such information within 30 days; and 
(3) Provide an explanation to a candidate for employment or employee being considered for 
promotion why disclosure of such information would violate local, state, or federal law, or 
interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall

individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.

(c) An employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for

(a) The notice required by § 20-871(b)(1) of the Code must include instructions for how an individual can 
request an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation under other laws, if 
available. Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or,

agent_answer:
An employer or employment agency can provide notice to a candidate for employment by using the following methods:

1. Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner at least 10 business days before the use of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT).
2. Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before the use of an AEDT.
3. Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before the use of an AEDT.

Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency must make the following information publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:

1. The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. This summary should include the source and explanation of the data used for the bias audit, the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT falling within an unknown category, and the number of applicants or candidates, selection or scoring rates, and impact ratios for all categories.
2. The distribution date of the AEDT.

The requirements for making this information publicly available can be met by providing an active hyperlink to a website containing the required summary of results and distribution date, as long as the link is clearly identified as a link to the results of the bias audit.

Additionally, the employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for at least 6 months after the latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.

question: What is the definition of test data and what are the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT?
reference_answer: Test data means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. A bias audit must calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, including sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories.
reference_context:
Document 18: (a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. If a bias audit uses test data, the summary of results of the 
bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was 
generated and obtained.  
 
Example 1: An employer is planning to use an AEDT for the first time. The employer may rely on a bias 
audit conducted using the historical data of other employers or employment agencies, or on a bias audit 
conducted using test data.

Document 19: 9 
 
Example 2: An employment agency has been using an AEDT for 6 months. The bias audit the 
employment agency relied on before its first use of the AEDT was conducted 10 months ago using test 
data. The employment agency will need an updated bias audit if it will continue to use the AEDT once 12 
months have passed since the bias audit it first relied on was conducted. The employment agency’s data 
from 6 months of use of the AEDT is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias 
audit. The employment agency may rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other employers and 
employment agencies if it provides its 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for use and 
consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.

agent_answer:
The definition of test data is data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 

The requirements for a bias audit of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) are as follows:

1. Historical Data: A bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT. This data can be from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency can only rely on a bias audit using historical data from other employers or agencies if they provided their own historical data to the independent auditor or if they have never used the AEDT.

2. Test Data: If there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. The summary of results of the bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was generated and obtained.

It is important to note that an employer or employment agency cannot rely on a bias audit conducted using test data if they have sufficient historical data available.

agent_answer:
The purpose of a bias audit is to assess the potential bias of an Artificial Intelligence Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) used by an employer or employment agency in the hiring or promotion process. It ensures that the AEDT does not discriminate against candidates based on sex, race/ethnicity, or intersectional categories.

An employer can rely on a bias audit in the following circumstances:
1. If the employer is planning to use an AEDT for the first time, they can rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from other employers or employment agencies, or a bias audit conducted using test data.
2. If an employment agency has been using an AEDT for less than a year, they can rely on a bias audit conducted using test data. However, they will need an updated bias audit once 12 months have passed since the first bias audit.
3. If an employer has been using an AEDT for more than a year and needs an updated bias audit, they can rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers or their own historical data.

In all cases, the employer or employment agency must provide their own historical data to the independent auditor if they want to rely on a bias audit using historical data from other sources. Additionally, an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit using test data if there is insufficient historical data available for a statistically significant bias audit.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of the purpose and circumstances under which an employer can rely on a bias audit, but it does not directly address the specific points mentioned in the ground truth. The ground truth focuses on calculating the impact ratio and the use of test data when historical data is insufficient, which is only partially covered by the agent's response.
reason_method2: The generated answer is mostly correct, addressing the purpose of a bias audit and when it can be relied upon, but it includes some unnecessary details and slightly deviates from the reference answer's focus on the impact ratio and specific reliance conditions.

question: What is the definition of an automated employment decision tool and what are the penalties for violating the requirements?
reference_answer: The term 'automated employment decision tool' means any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500 for each subsequent violation.
reference_context:
Document 1: Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.

§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required. In the city, any employer or employment agency that uses an automated employment decision tool to screen an employee or a
candidate who has applied for a position for an employment decision shall notify each such employee or candidate who resides in the city of the
following:
      1.   That an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with the assessment or evaluation of such employee or candidate that
resides in the city. Such notice shall be made no less than ten business days before such use and allow a candidate to request an alternative selection
process or accommodation;
      2.   The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

Document 2: The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-873 Enforcement.
The corporation counsel or such other persons designated by the corporation counsel on behalf of the department may initiate in any court of competent
jurisdiction any action or proceeding that may be appropriate or necessary for correction of any violation issued pursuant this subchapter, including
mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.

agent_answer:
According to the provided context, the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool are as follows:

1. Bias Audit: Before using an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision, the tool must have undergone a bias audit conducted within the past year.

2. Public Availability of Audit Results: A summary of the most recent bias audit results of the tool, along with the distribution date of the tool to which the audit applies, must be made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency before using the tool.

3. Notice to Employees/Candidates: Employers or employment agencies using an automated employment decision tool must notify each employee or candidate residing in the city of the following:
   a. The use of an automated employment decision tool in the assessment or evaluation process.
   b. The job qualifications and characteristics that the tool will use in the assessment.
   c. If not disclosed on the website, information about the type of data collected, the source of such data, and the data retention policy. This information must be provided upon written request within 30 days.

Penalties for violating these requirements are not explicitly mentioned in the provided context. It is advisable to refer to the relevant laws or regulations for specific penalties or enforcement mechanisms.

question: What are the requirements for an employer or employment agency to comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, and what information must be made publicly available before the use of an AEDT?
reference_answer: An employer or employment agency must provide notice to a candidate for employment in a clear and conspicuous manner at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT. The information that must be made publicly available before the use of an AEDT includes the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT, a summary of the results, and the distribution date of the AEDT.
reference_context:
Document 20: The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.  
(b) The requirements of subdivision (a) of this section may be met with an active hyperlink to a website 
containing the required summary of results and distribution date, provided that the link is clearly identified 
as a link to results of the bias audit. 
(c) An employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for 
at least 6 months after its latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.   
 
§ 5-304 Notice to Candidates and Employees.  
(a) The notice required by § 20-871(b)(1) of the Code must include instructions for how an individual can 
request an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation under other laws, if 
available. Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT.

(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT. 
(c) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide

following: 
(1) Provide notice in a written policy or procedure that is provided to employees at least 10 
business days before use of an AEDT;

Example 2: An employment agency has been using an AEDT for 6 months. The bias audit the 
employment agency relied on before its first use of the AEDT was conducted 10 months ago using test 
data. The employment agency will need an updated bias audit if it will continue to use the AEDT once 12 
months have passed since the bias audit it first relied on was conducted. The employment agency’s data 
from 6 months of use of the AEDT is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias 
audit. The employment agency may rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other employers and 
employment agencies if it provides its 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for use and 
consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.

agent_answer:
To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must provide notice to candidates for employment and employees being considered for promotion at least 10 business days before the use of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT). This notice can be provided through various methods:

1. Notice on the employment section of the employer or employment agency's website in a clear and conspicuous manner.
2. Notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before the use of an AEDT.
3. Notice via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before the use of an AEDT.

Before the use of an AEDT, the employer or employment agency must make the following information publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:

1. The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. This summary should include the source and explanation of the data used for the bias audit, the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT falling within an unknown category, and the number of applicants or candidates, selection or scoring rates, and impact ratios for all categories.
2. The distribution date of the AEDT.

The requirements for making this information publicly available can be met by providing an active hyperlink to a website containing the required summary of results and distribution date, as long as the link is clearly identified as a link to the results of the bias audit.

Additionally, the employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for at least 6 months after the latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.

agent_answer:
According to the provided context, for an employer or employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool, the following requirements must be met:

1. The tool must have undergone a bias audit conducted within one year prior to its use.
2. A summary of the most recent bias audit results, along with the distribution date of the tool, must be publicly available on the employer or employment agency's website before using the tool.

In addition, the employer or employment agency must provide the following notices to employees or candidates residing in the city:

1. Notify them that an automated employment decision tool will be used in assessing or evaluating them. This notice must be given at least ten business days before the tool's use and allow the candidate to request an alternative selection process or accommodation.
2. Inform them of the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in assessing them. This notice must be given at least ten business days before the tool's use.
3. If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, provide information about the type of data collected for the tool, the source of such data, and the data retention policy upon written request. This information must be provided within 30 days of the written request, except where prohibited by law or interfering with a law enforcement investigation.

Regarding penalties for violations of the subchapter, the following can be imposed:

1. A civil penalty of up to $500 for the first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation.
2. A civil penalty of not less than $500 nor more than $1,500 for each subsequent violation.
3. Each day an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of the subchapter constitutes a separate violation.
4. Failure to provide any required notice to a candidate or employee constitutes a separate violation.

Proceedings to recover civil penalties are conducted in a tribunal established within the office of administrative trials and hearings or within any designated city agency.

question: What is the definition of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' and what is a 'Bias audit'?
reference_answer: The term 'automated employment decision tool' means any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. A 'bias audit' means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported by employers.

Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read

Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1.

of the Code.

249.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.

agent_answer:
The definition of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' is a computational process that uses machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to issue simplified output, such as a score, classification, or recommendation, that substantially assists or replaces discretionary decision making in employment decisions that impact individuals. It does not include tools that do not automate or substantially assist decision-making processes and do not materially impact individuals.

A 'Bias audit' refers to an impartial evaluation conducted by an independent auditor. It involves testing an automated employment decision tool to assess its disparate impact on individuals of different categories, as required to be reported by employers under federal regulations. The purpose of a bias audit is to identify and address any biases or discriminatory effects in the tool's decision-making process.

question: What are the requirements for a bias audit and what is test data?
reference_answer: The requirements for a bias audit include calculating the selection rate and impact ratio for each category. Test data is the data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data.
reference_context:
Document 5: These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law. 
 
Specifically, these new rules will: 
 
Define terms; 
 
Clarify the requirements for a bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for the published results of the required bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for notices that employers and employment agencies must provide to employees 
and candidates for employment; and  
 
Clarify other obligations for the employer or employment agency.  
 
The Department initially proposed a version of these rules in September 2022. The Department received 
comments from the public, including from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and 
advocacy organizations. Various issues raised in the comments led to a second version of the proposed rules, 
published in December 2022. Those changes included:  
 
Modifying the definition of AEDT to ensure greater focus; 
 
Clarifying that an “independent auditor” may not be employed or have a financial interest in an employer 
or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to use an AEDT or in a vendor that developed or 
distributed the AEDT; 
 
Revising the required calculation to be performed where an AEDT scores candidates;

Document 6: 2 
 
 
Clarifying that the required “impact ratio” must be calculated separately to compare sex categories, 
race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories; 
 
Clarifying the types of data that may be used to conduct a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying that multiple employers using the same AEDT may rely on the same bias audit so long as they 
provide historical data, if available, for the independent auditor to consider in such bias audit; and 
 
Clarifying that an AEDT may not be used if its most recent bias audit is more than a year old; 
 
The Department received comments about the second version of the proposed rule from the public, including 
from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and advocacy organizations. Various 
issues raised in the comments resulted in changes that are present in these final rules. These changes include: 
 
Modifying the definition of “machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence” 
to expand its scope; 
 
Adding a requirement that the bias audit indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are 
not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category, and requiring that number 
be included in the summary of results; 
 
Allowing an independent auditor to exclude a category that comprises less than 2% of the data being 
used for the bias audit from the calculations of impact ratio; 
 
Clarifying the examples of a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted using the 
historical data of other employers or employment agencies; 
 
Providing examples of when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted with 
historical data, test data, or historical data from other employers and employment agencies; 
 
Clarifying that the number of applicants in a category and scoring rate of a category, if applicable, must 
be included in the summary of results. 
 
New material is underlined. 
[Deleted material is in brackets.] 
 
“Shall” and “must” denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this 
department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

Document 15: 7 
 
(3) Calculate the impact ratio for each category;  
(4) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision 
separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (i.e., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates); and  
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
(d) Notwithstanding the requirements of paragraphs (2) and (3) of subdivision (b) and paragraphs (3) and 
(4) of subdivision (c), an independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of 
the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. Where such a 
category is excluded, the summary of results must include the independent auditor’s justification for the 
exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded 
category.  
 
Example: An employer uses an AEDT to score applicants for “culture fit.” To do so, the employer must 
ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than a year before the use of the AEDT.

agent_answer:
The requirements for a bias audit are outlined in Section 5-302 of the New York City Council's regulations. According to the regulations:

1. Historical Data: A bias audit must use historical data of the Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) being audited. This historical data can be from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency can only rely on a bias audit conducted using the historical data of other employers or agencies if they provided their own historical data to the independent auditor or if they have never used the AEDT.

2. Test Data: If there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. Test data is data specifically generated and obtained for the purpose of conducting the bias audit. If test data is used, the summary of the bias audit results must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data was generated and obtained.

In summary, a bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT, but in certain circumstances, an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other entities or use test data if there is not enough historical data available.

Test data refers to data that is specifically generated and obtained for the purpose of conducting a bias audit. It is used when there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. The test data is used to evaluate the impact of the AEDT on employment decisions and assess any potential biases. The summary of the bias audit results must explain why historical data was not used and provide details on how the test data was generated and obtained.

question: What must an employer or employment agency provide in a bias audit and what are the options for providing notice to a candidate for employment?
reference_answer: An employer or employment agency must provide the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. They can provide notice on the employment section of its website, in a job posting, or via U.S. mail or e-mail.

(d) To comply with § 20-871(b)(3) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must: 
(1) Provide information on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous 
manner about its AEDT data retention policy, the type of data collected for the AEDT, and the 
source of the data; 
(2) Post instructions on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner

(3) Provide an explanation to a candidate for employment or employee being considered for

agent_answer:
In a bias audit, an employer or employment agency must provide the following information:

1. Historical Data: The bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT (Automated Employment Decision Tool) that is being audited. The historical data can be from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency can only rely on a bias audit that uses historical data from other employers or agencies if they have provided their own historical data to the independent auditor or if they have never used the AEDT.

2. Test Data: If there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. The summary of results of the bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was generated and obtained.

As for providing notice to a candidate for employment, the context does not provide specific information about it. However, notice to a candidate for employment typically includes informing them about the use of an AEDT in the hiring process, explaining how the AEDT works, and providing information about the candidate's rights and options for addressing any potential bias or discrimination. The specific requirements for providing notice may vary depending on local laws and regulations.

The agent's answer does not include these details.

question: What are the requirements and purpose of conducting a bias audit?
reference_answer: The requirements for conducting a bias audit include excluding categories that represent less than 2% of the data from impact ratio calculations. The purpose of conducting a bias audit is to assess the impact of the AEDT on different categories, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories.

metadata: {'question_type': 'double', 'seed_document_id': 16, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What are the requirements for conducting a bias audit?', 'answer': 'An independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio.'}, {'question': 'What is the purpose of conducting a bias audit?', 'answer': 'To assess the impact of the AEDT on different categories, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The requirements and purpose of conducting a bias audit are outlined in Section 5-301 and Section 5-302 of the provided context information.

The purpose of a bias audit is to assess the potential bias and fairness of an Artificial Intelligence Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) used by an employer or employment agency in the hiring or promotion process. The audit aims to identify any disparities or adverse impact on different categories of candidates, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories.

The requirements for conducting a bias audit include:

1. Calculation of selection rate and impact ratio for each category: The audit must calculate the selection rate (percentage of candidates selected) and impact ratio (ratio of selection rates between different categories) for each category, such as sex and race/ethnicity.

2. Separate calculations for different categories: The audit must separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories.

3. Calculation for each group (if applicable): If the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups, such as leadership styles, the audit must perform the calculations mentioned above for each group.

4. Exclusion of categories representing less than 2% of the data (optional): An independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of the data from the required calculations for impact ratio. However, the summary of results must include the justification for the exclusion and the relevant data for the excluded category.

In addition to these requirements, the bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT to assess its potential bias. However, if insufficient historical data is available, the audit may use test data. The summary of results must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data was generated and obtained.

The purpose of these requirements is to ensure that employers and employment agencies are aware of any potential bias in the AEDT and take appropriate measures to address it. By conducting a bias audit, they can identify and rectify any disparities or adverse impact on different categories of candidates, promoting fairness and equal opportunities in the hiring or promotion process.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of the requirements and purpose of conducting a bias audit, which aligns with the ground truth. The ground truth is a concise summary, while the agent's answer elaborates on the same points, including the exclusion of categories representing less than 2% of the data and the assessment of the AEDT's impact on different categories.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly addresses the purpose and requirements of conducting a bias audit, providing detailed information, but it includes some unnecessary elaboration that slightly detracts from the main focus.

question: What is the meaning of 'simplified output' and 'impact ratio'?
reference_answer: 'Simplified output' refers to a prediction or classification in the fields of machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence. 'Impact ratio' can either refer to the selection rate for a category divided by the selection rate of the most selected category, or the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the highest scoring category.
reference_context:
Document 10: Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example. If 100 Hispanic women apply for a position and 40 are selected for an interview after use of an 
AEDT, the selection rate for Hispanic women is 40/100 or 40%.  
 
Simplified output. “Simplified output” means a prediction or classification as specified in the definition 
for “machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence.” A simplified output 
may take the form of a score (e.g., rating a candidate’s estimated technical skills), tag or categorization 
(e.g., categorizing a candidate’s resume based on key words, assigning a skill or trait to a candidate), 
recommendation (e.g., whether a candidate should be given an interview), or ranking (e.g., arranging a 
list of candidates based on how well their cover letters match the job description). It does not refer to the 
output from analytical tools that translate or transcribe existing text, e.g., convert a resume from a PDF 
or transcribe a video or audio interview.

agent_answer:
The term "simplified output" refers to a prediction or classification generated by a machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence system. It can take the form of a score, tag, categorization, recommendation, or ranking. It does not include the output from tools that simply translate or transcribe existing text.

On the other hand, "impact ratio" is a measure used in a bias audit of an automated employment decision tool (AEDT). It calculates the effect of the AEDT on different categories. There are two types of impact ratios: selection rate and scoring rate. The selection rate impact ratio compares the selection rate of a specific category to the selection rate of the most selected category. The scoring rate impact ratio compares the scoring rate of a category to the scoring rate of the highest scoring category. These ratios help assess the potential bias or disparate impact of an AEDT on different groups.

reason_method2: The generated answer correctly explains both terms and covers all components of the user query, but it includes some unnecessary details about bias audits that are not part of the reference answer.

question: What is a bias audit and what information should be publicly available before using an AEDT?
reference_answer: A bias audit is a process that calculates the selection rate and impact ratio of an AEDT on different categories such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. Before using an AEDT, an employer or employment agency must make publicly available the date of the most recent bias audit and a summary of the results, including the source and explanation of the data used, the number of individuals falling within an unknown category, and the selection rates and impact ratios for all categories.

Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category.

using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical

metadata: {'question_type': 'double', 'seed_document_id': 11, 'topic': 'Definitions', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What is a bias audit?', 'answer': 'A bias audit is a process that calculates the selection rate and impact ratio of an AEDT on different categories such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories.'}, {'question': 'What information should be publicly available before using an AEDT?', 'answer': 'Before using an AEDT, an employer or employment agency must make publicly available the date of the most recent bias audit and a summary of the results, including the source and explanation of the data used, the number of individuals falling within an unknown category, and the selection rates and impact ratios for all categories.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
A bias audit is a process conducted to assess the potential bias or discriminatory impact of an Artificial Intelligence Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) used by an employer or employment agency. The purpose of a bias audit is to ensure that the AEDT is fair and does not disproportionately favor or disadvantage certain groups based on characteristics such as sex, race, or ethnicity.

Before using an AEDT, the following information should be publicly available on the employment section of the employer or employment agency's website:

1. Date of the most recent bias audit: This indicates when the AEDT was last assessed for bias.

2. Summary of results: This includes a summary of the bias audit results, which should include the source and explanation of the data used for the audit. It should also include the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT who fall within an unknown category.

3. Number of applicants or candidates: This provides the total number of applicants or candidates who were assessed by the AEDT.

4. Selection or scoring rates: This indicates the rate at which applicants or candidates were selected or scored by the AEDT.

5. Impact ratios: This calculates the impact of the AEDT on different categories, such as sex, race, or ethnicity. It compares the selection or scoring rates of different groups to assess if there is any disproportionate impact.

6. Distribution date of the AEDT: This indicates when the AEDT was distributed or made available for use.

The information can be provided in a clear and conspicuous manner on the website, or it can be provided through an active hyperlink to a website containing the required information. The employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for at least 6 months after the latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer accurately describes what a bias audit is and lists the necessary information that should be publicly available before using an AEDT. It includes details such as the date of the most recent bias audit, a summary of the results, the number of applicants or candidates, selection or scoring rates, and impact ratios, which align with the ground truth answer.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly defines a bias audit and outlines the necessary information to be publicly available before using an AEDT, but it includes some additional details that are not specified in the reference answer, which slightly affects its completeness.

question: What is the definition of 'employment decision' and what are the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool?
reference_answer: The term 'employment decision' means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city. It is unlawful for an employer or employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool unless it has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior and a summary of the results of the most recent bias audit has been made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency.
reference_context:
Document 1: Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required. In the city, any employer or employment agency that uses an automated employment decision tool to screen an employee or a
candidate who has applied for a position for an employment decision shall notify each such employee or candidate who resides in the city of the
following:
      1.   That an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with the assessment or evaluation of such employee or candidate that
resides in the city. Such notice shall be made no less than ten business days before such use and allow a candidate to request an alternative selection
process or accommodation;
      2.   The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
