Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

Document 2: The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-873 Enforcement.
The corporation counsel or such other persons designated by the corporation counsel on behalf of the department may initiate in any court of competent
jurisdiction any action or proceeding that may be appropriate or necessary for correction of any violation issued pursuant this subchapter, including
mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.

agent_answer:
The term "employment decision" refers to the process of screening candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.

The requirements for using an automated employment decision tool in the city are as follows:

1. The tool must have undergone a bias audit conducted within one year prior to its use.
2. A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit, along with the distribution date of the tool, must be publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency before the tool is used.

Additionally, employers or employment agencies that use an automated employment decision tool must provide the following notices to employees or candidates residing in the city:

1. A notice must be given at least ten business days before the use of the tool, informing the employee or candidate that an automated employment decision tool will be used in their assessment or evaluation. The notice should also allow the candidate to request an alternative selection process or accommodation.
2. A notice must be given at least ten business days before the use of the tool, specifying the job qualifications and characteristics that the tool will use in assessing the candidate or employee.
3. If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment decision tool, the source of such data, and the data retention policy of the employer or employment agency must be provided upon written request by a candidate or employee. This information should be provided within 30 days of the written request, except in cases where disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

question: What are the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT and what is test data?
reference_answer: The requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT are to calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category and compare the selection rates to determine an impact ratio. Test data is data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data.

§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

(3) Calculate the impact ratio for each category;

ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino

the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. Where such a

Example: An employer uses an AEDT to score applicants for “culture fit.” To do so, the employer must 
ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than a year before the use of the AEDT.
metadata: {'question_type': 'double', 'seed_document_id': 6, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What are the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT?', 'answer': 'A bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category and compare the selection rates to determine an impact ratio.'}, {'question': 'What is test data?', 'answer': 'Test data is data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT (Automated Employment Decision Tool) are outlined in section 5-301 of the given context. Here are the key requirements:

1. Timing: An employer or employment agency cannot use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.

2. Selection Rate Calculation: The bias audit must calculate the selection rate for each category. This involves determining the percentage of candidates selected for employment or promotion in each category.

3. Impact Ratio Calculation: The bias audit must calculate the impact ratio for each category. The impact ratio measures the relative impact of the AEDT on different categories. It is calculated by dividing the selection rate of one category by the selection rate of another category.

4. Separate Calculations: The calculations for selection rate and impact ratio must be performed separately for sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race.

5. Group Calculations: If the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups, the calculations must be performed for each group as well.

6. Unknown Category: The bias audit must indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT who fall within an unknown category and are not included in the required calculations.

In addition to these requirements, the context also mentions the concept of test data. Test data refers to data that is used in a bias audit when there is insufficient historical data available. If an employer or employment agency does not have enough historical data to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, they may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. The summary of results of the bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was generated and obtained.

While the agent's answer is more detailed than the ground truth, it covers all the key points mentioned in the ground truth answer.

question: What is the purpose of a bias audit and under what circumstances can an employer rely on it using historical data from other employers?
reference_answer: The purpose of a bias audit is to calculate the impact ratio and selection rate of an AEDT on different categories. An employer can rely on a bias audit using historical data from other employers if they provided their own historical data or if they have never used the AEDT.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

metadata: {'question_type': 'double', 'seed_document_id': 17, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What is the purpose of a bias audit?', 'answer': 'A bias audit is conducted to calculate the impact ratio and selection rate of an AEDT on different categories such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories.'}, {'question': 'Under what circumstances can an employer rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from other employers?', 'answer': 'An employer can rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses historical data from other employers if they provided their own historical data or if they have never used the AEDT.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The purpose of a bias audit is to assess the impact of an Artificial Intelligence Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) on different categories of candidates, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. It is conducted to identify any potential biases or discriminatory effects of the AEDT in the hiring or promotion process.

An employer can rely on a bias audit using historical data from other employers in two circumstances:

1. If the employer has never used the AEDT before: In this case, the employer can rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from other employers or employment agencies.

2. If the employer has used the AEDT before but does not have sufficient historical data: If an employer has used the AEDT but does not have enough historical data to conduct a statistically significant bias audit, they can rely on a bias audit using historical data from other employers or employment agencies. However, in this case, the employer must provide their own historical data from their use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit.

In both circumstances, the employer must ensure that the bias audit meets the requirements outlined in the regulations, such as calculating selection rates, impact ratios, and including the necessary categories for analysis (sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories).
correctness_reason: The agent's answer accurately describes the purpose of a bias audit and the circumstances under which an employer can rely on historical data from other employers. It includes details about calculating selection rates and impact ratios, and it correctly identifies the conditions under which an employer can use historical data from other employers.

In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision unless: 1. Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and 2. § 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:

substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means:

made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

metadata: {'question_type': 'double', 'seed_document_id': 7, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What is the definition of an automated employment decision tool?', 'answer': "The term 'automated employment decision tool' means any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons."}, {'question': 'What are the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool?', 'answer': 'In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision unless: 1. Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and 2. A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
An automated employment decision tool is a computational process that uses machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to issue simplified output, such as a score, classification, or recommendation. It is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making in employment decisions that affect individuals. However, it does not include tools that do not automate or substantially assist decision-making processes and do not materially impact individuals, such as antivirus software or calculators.

The requirements for using an automated employment decision tool in the city are as follows:

1. Bias Audit: Before using an automated employment decision tool, it must undergo a bias audit conducted by an independent auditor. The audit evaluates the tool's disparate impact on individuals of different categories, as required to be reported by employers under federal regulations.

2. Public Availability of Audit Results: The employer or employment agency must make a summary of the most recent bias audit results publicly available on their website. This summary should include the distribution date of the tool to which the audit applies. This information must be available before using the tool.

3. Notices to Employees/Candidates: If an employer or employment agency uses an automated employment decision tool to screen employees or candidates, they must provide the following notices:

   a. Notice of Tool Use: At least ten business days before using the tool, the employer or agency must notify employees or candidates residing in the city that an automated employment decision tool will be used in their assessment or evaluation. This notice should also allow candidates to request an alternative selection process or accommodation.

   b. Notice of Job Qualifications: At least ten business days before using the tool, the employer or agency must inform employees or candidates of the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in their assessment.

   c. Data Information: If not already disclosed on the employer or agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the tool, the source of the data, and the data retention policy must be provided upon written request by a candidate or employee. This information should be provided within 30 days of the request, except where disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer includes additional details and requirements that are not present in the ground truth answer. The ground truth focuses on the definition and two main requirements: a bias audit and public availability of audit results. The agent's answer, while detailed and informative, goes beyond the scope of the ground truth by including notices to employees/candidates and data information requirements.
reason_method2: The generated answer accurately defines an automated employment decision tool and covers the requirements for its use, but it includes some additional details that are not part of the reference answer, which slightly detracts from its precision.

Violating the requirements for such tools can result in civil penalties, with a maximum penalty of $500 for a first violation and increasing penalties for subsequent violations, ranging from $500 to $1,500.

question: What is the relationship between the definition of 'test data' in a bias audit and the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT?
reference_answer: In a bias audit, 'test data' refers to the data used for the audit that is not historical data. On the other hand, a bias audit of an AEDT requires calculating the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, including sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. Therefore, the definition of 'test data' in a bias audit is distinct from the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT, but both are crucial components of ensuring fairness and identifying potential biases in automated systems.
reference_context:
Document 18: (a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. If a bias audit uses test data, the summary of results of the 
bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was 
generated and obtained.  
 
Example 1: An employer is planning to use an AEDT for the first time. The employer may rely on a bias 
audit conducted using the historical data of other employers or employment agencies, or on a bias audit 
conducted using test data.

Document 19: 9 
 
Example 2: An employment agency has been using an AEDT for 6 months. The bias audit the 
employment agency relied on before its first use of the AEDT was conducted 10 months ago using test 
data. The employment agency will need an updated bias audit if it will continue to use the AEDT once 12 
months have passed since the bias audit it first relied on was conducted. The employment agency’s data 
from 6 months of use of the AEDT is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias 
audit. The employment agency may rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other employers and 
employment agencies if it provides its 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for use and 
consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.

Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers

question: What are the differences and similarities between the requirements for publicly available information on the employment section of a website before the use of an AEDT and the options for an employer or employment agency to provide notice to a candidate for employment regarding the use of an AEDT?
reference_answer: Before the use of an AEDT, the employment section of a website must publicly provide the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. Additionally, employers or employment agencies have the options to provide notice on the employment section of their website, in a job posting, or via U.S. mail or e-mail. These requirements and options ensure transparency and communication regarding the use of an AEDT in the employment process.
reference_context:

data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.  
(b) The requirements of subdivision (a) of this section may be met with an active hyperlink to a website 
containing the required summary of results and distribution date, provided that the link is clearly identified 
as a link to results of the bias audit. 
(c) An employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for 
at least 6 months after its latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.   
 
§ 5-304 Notice to Candidates and Employees.  
(a) The notice required by § 20-871(b)(1) of the Code must include instructions for how an individual can 
request an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation under other laws, if 
available. Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT.

(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide

(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;

(2) Post instructions on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner

employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test

§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following

(1)

The distribution date of the AEDT.

agent_answer:
The requirements for publicly available information on the employment section of a website before the use of an AEDT and the options for an employer or employment agency to provide notice to a candidate for employment regarding the use of an AEDT have some similarities and differences. 

Similarities:
1. Both requirements aim to provide transparency and information to candidates and employees about the use of AEDTs in the employment process.
2. Both requirements specify a minimum notice period of at least 10 business days before the use of an AEDT.
3. Both requirements allow for the use of the employment section of a website to fulfill the notice requirement.

Differences:
1. The requirement for publicly available information on the employment section of a website focuses on providing information about the bias audit results and the distribution date of the AEDT. It includes details such as the source and explanation of the data used, the number of individuals assessed, selection or scoring rates, and impact ratios for all categories.
2. The options for providing notice to a candidate for employment include: 
   a) Notice on the employment section of the website
   b) Notice in a job posting
   c) Notice via U.S. mail or e-mail
3. The notice to candidates must include instructions for requesting an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation if available, but there is no requirement for employers to provide an alternative selection process.
4. The notice to employees being considered for promotion can be provided through a written policy or procedure, a job posting, or via U.S. mail or e-mail.

In summary, the requirements for publicly available information focus on providing detailed information about the AEDT's bias audit results, while the options for providing notice to candidates and employees focus on informing them about the use of AEDTs and their rights to request alternatives or accommodations.

The agent's answer introduces additional elements such as minimum notice periods, instructions for requesting alternative selection processes, and specific details about bias audit results that are not part of the ground truth.
reason_method2: The generated answer addresses multiple components of the user query correctly but contains some inaccuracies regarding the specifics of the requirements and options, particularly the mention of a minimum notice period which is not part of the reference answer.

question: How does the data requirements for a bias audit relate to the process of assessing the impact of an AEDT on different categories?
reference_answer: A bias audit is a process used to assess the impact of an AEDT on different categories, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. The data requirements for a bias audit involve using historical data of the AEDT. However, if there is insufficient historical data available, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. In both cases, the goal is to evaluate any potential biases and disparities in the AEDT's impact on different categories.
reference_context:
Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.
metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'seed_document_id': 11, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What is a bias audit?', 'answer': 'A bias audit is a process used to assess the impact of an AEDT on different categories, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories.'}, {'question': 'What are the data requirements for a bias audit?', 'answer': 'A bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT, but if insufficient historical data is available, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The data requirements for a bias audit are essential for assessing the impact of an AEDT (Automated Employment Decision-Making Tool) on different categories. The bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT, which can be from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the tool. This data is used to calculate various metrics and ratios to determine the impact of the AEDT on different categories such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories.

For the assessment of selection or promotion decisions, the bias audit must calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for each category. The selection rate measures the percentage of applicants or employees selected from each category, while the impact ratio compares the selection rate of one category to a reference category (usually the category with the highest selection rate). This helps identify any disparities or biases in the AEDT's outcomes for different categories.

Similarly, for the assessment of scoring decisions, the bias audit must calculate the median score for the full sample of applicants and the scoring rate and impact ratio for each category. The scoring rate measures the percentage of individuals in each category who receive a certain score, while the impact ratio compares the scoring rate of one category to a reference category. Again, these calculations help identify any disparities or biases in the AEDT's scoring outcomes for different categories.

The data requirements also include conducting separate calculations for different categories, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. This ensures that the impact of the AEDT on each category is assessed individually. Additionally, the bias audit must indicate the number of individuals who fall within an unknown category and are not included in the calculations.

Overall, the data requirements for a bias audit provide a systematic approach to assess the impact of an AEDT on different categories and identify any potential biases or disparities in its outcomes.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of the data requirements for a bias audit and how they relate to assessing the impact of an AEDT on different categories. It covers the use of historical data, the calculation of selection rates, impact ratios, and the assessment of different categories, which aligns with the ground truth answer.
reason_method2: The generated answer is mostly correct and addresses all components of the user query, but it includes some unnecessary detail that slightly detracts from its clarity.

question: Where can a proceeding to recover a civil penalty be returnable, and who has the authority to initiate an action or proceeding for correction of any violation?
reference_answer: A proceeding to recover a civil penalty authorized by this subchapter can be returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings. The authority to initiate an action or proceeding for correction of any violation lies with the corporation counsel or other persons designated by the corporation counsel on behalf of the department, who may initiate such action or proceeding in any court of competent jurisdiction as deemed appropriate or necessary.

question: What is the relationship between the definition of an automated employment decision tool and the requirements for using such a tool?
reference_answer: An automated employment decision tool is defined as a computational process that issues simplified output, derived from various technologies. The requirements for using such a tool state that it is unlawful to use it for screening candidates or employees unless it has undergone a bias audit within the past year. Therefore, the definition provides the general understanding of the tool, while the requirements outline the legal restrictions and conditions for its use.
reference_context:
Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

Document 7: 3 
 
Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code. 
 
Employment Agency. “Employment agency” means “Employment agency” as defined by 6 RCNY § 5-
249.  
 
Historical data.
metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'seed_document_id': 0, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What is the definition of an automated employment decision tool?', 'answer': "The term 'automated employment decision tool' means any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output."}, {'question': 'What are the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool?', 'answer': 'In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision unless the tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The definition of an automated employment decision tool is provided in § 20-870 of the New York City Council's regulations. It defines an automated employment decision tool as a computational process that uses machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to issue simplified output that assists or replaces discretionary decision making in employment decisions. However, certain tools that do not automate or substantially assist decision-making processes and do not materially impact individuals are excluded from this definition.

The requirements for using an automated employment decision tool are outlined in § 20-871. According to these requirements, it is unlawful for an employer or employment agency in New York City to use such a tool to screen candidates or employees for employment decisions unless certain conditions are met. These conditions include:

1. The tool must have undergone a bias audit conducted within the past year.
2. A summary of the most recent bias audit results, along with the distribution date of the tool, must be publicly available on the employer or employment agency's website before using the tool.
3. Employers or employment agencies must provide notices to employees or candidates residing in the city, informing them that an automated employment decision tool will be used and providing information about the job qualifications and characteristics that the tool will assess. If not disclosed on the website, information about the type of data collected, its source, and the data retention policy must be provided upon written request.

In summary, the definition of an automated employment decision tool sets the scope of tools covered by the regulations, while the requirements specify the conditions that must be met for using such tools in New York City.

question: What is the relationship between test data and the requirements for a bias audit, and how do they differ?
reference_answer: Test data refers to the data used specifically for conducting a bias audit, which is not historical data. On the other hand, the requirements for a bias audit include calculating the selection rate and impact ratio for various categories, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. While test data is a subset of the data used in a bias audit, the requirements for a bias audit involve specific calculations and analysis of different categories to identify and address biases.
reference_context:
Document 18: (a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. If a bias audit uses test data, the summary of results of the 
bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was 
generated and obtained.  
 
Example 1: An employer is planning to use an AEDT for the first time. The employer may rely on a bias 
audit conducted using the historical data of other employers or employment agencies, or on a bias audit 
conducted using test data.

(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has

agent_answer:
The relationship between test data and the requirements for a bias audit is that test data can be used as a substitute for historical data when conducting a bias audit. The requirements for a bias audit state that historical data of the Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) must be used, but if there is insufficient historical data available, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit using test data.

However, there are differences between using historical data and test data in a bias audit. Historical data refers to the actual data collected from the use of the AEDT by employers or employment agencies over a period of time. It provides a comprehensive and accurate representation of the tool's impact on employment decisions.

On the other hand, test data is generated specifically for the purpose of conducting a bias audit when there is a lack of sufficient historical data. Test data may not reflect the real-world scenarios and diversity of candidates or employees. The summary of results in a bias audit using test data must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data was generated and obtained.

In summary, while historical data is the preferred choice for a bias audit, test data can be used as an alternative when there is a lack of sufficient historical data. However, test data may not provide the same level of accuracy and representativeness as historical data.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of the relationship between test data and historical data in the context of a bias audit, but it does not directly address the specific requirements for a bias audit as outlined in the ground truth. The ground truth focuses on the specific calculations and analysis required for a bias audit, such as selection rate and impact ratio for various categories, which the agent's answer does not mention.
reason_method2: The generated answer partially addresses the relationship and differences between test data and bias audit requirements, but it contains inaccuracies regarding the role of historical data and lacks clarity on specific requirements for a bias audit.

question: What are the differences and similarities between 'selection rate' and 'scoring rate', and how do they relate to each other?
reference_answer: 'Selection rate' refers to the rate at which individuals are selected or classified in a hiring process or by an AEDT, while 'scoring rate' pertains to the rate at which individuals receive a score above the sample's median score, calculated by an AEDT. Both rates involve evaluating individuals based on certain criteria, but 'selection rate' focuses on advancement in a process, while 'scoring rate' focuses on achieving a score above a threshold. In some cases, the two rates may be related, such as when a higher 'scoring rate' leads to a higher 'selection rate' for certain categories of individuals.
reference_context:
Document 10: Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example. If 100 Hispanic women apply for a position and 40 are selected for an interview after use of an 
AEDT, the selection rate for Hispanic women is 40/100 or 40%.  
 
Simplified output. “Simplified output” means a prediction or classification as specified in the definition 
for “machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence.” A simplified output 
may take the form of a score (e.g., rating a candidate’s estimated technical skills), tag or categorization 
(e.g., categorizing a candidate’s resume based on key words, assigning a skill or trait to a candidate), 
recommendation (e.g., whether a candidate should be given an interview), or ranking (e.g., arranging a 
list of candidates based on how well their cover letters match the job description). It does not refer to the 
output from analytical tools that translate or transcribe existing text, e.g., convert a resume from a PDF 
or transcribe a video or audio interview.

rate of the most selected category or (2) the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the 
highest scoring category.

for which a computer at least in part identifies the inputs, the relative importance placed

agent_answer:
The differences between 'selection rate' and 'scoring rate' are as follows:

1. Selection Rate: The selection rate refers to the percentage of candidates or employees selected by an automated employment decision tool (AEDT) for a particular category, such as sex, race/ethnicity, or intersectional categories. It calculates the proportion of individuals selected from the total number of applicants in each category.

2. Scoring Rate: The scoring rate, on the other hand, is used when an AEDT assigns scores to candidates based on certain criteria, such as "culture fit." The scoring rate represents the percentage of individuals in each category who receive a certain score or above.

Despite these differences, both selection rate and scoring rate are used to assess the impact of an AEDT on different categories. They help identify any potential bias or disparities in the selection or scoring process based on sex, race/ethnicity, or intersectional categories.

In terms of their relationship, the selection rate is used when an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion, while the scoring rate is used when an AEDT scores candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion. Both rates are calculated separately for each category and are part of the bias audit process to ensure fairness and compliance with the law.

Additionally, the ground truth highlights the potential relationship between the two rates, which the agent's answer only partially addresses.

question: What calculations are required in the bias audit and when can an independent auditor exclude a category from these calculations?
reference_answer: In the bias audit, calculations include determining the impact ratio for each category and assessing the impact of the AEDT on various demographic categories. An independent auditor can exclude a category from the calculations if it represents less than 2% of the data being used for the audit.

metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'seed_document_id': 16, 'topic': 'Metrics/Data', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What are the calculations required in the bias audit?', 'answer': 'The calculations required in the bias audit include calculating the impact ratio for each category and separately calculating the impact of the AEDT on sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race.'}, {'question': 'When can an independent auditor exclude a category from the bias audit calculations?', 'answer': 'An independent auditor can exclude a category that represents less than 2% of the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
In the bias audit, the following calculations are required:

1. Selection Rate: Calculate the selection rate for each category. This calculates the percentage of applicants selected for each category.

2. Impact Ratio: Calculate the impact ratio for each category. This measures the impact of the AEDT on the selection of candidates from different categories. It is calculated by dividing the selection rate of one category by the selection rate of a reference category (usually the category with the highest selection rate).

3. Intersectional Categories: Ensure that the calculations for selection rate and impact ratio are separately calculated for sex categories, race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race.

4. Group Classification: If the AEDT classifies candidates into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles), the calculations in paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 must be performed for each group.

5. Unknown Category: Indicate the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that are not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category.

An independent auditor may exclude a category from these calculations if it represents less than 2% of the data being used for the bias audit. However, the summary of results must include the auditor's justification for the exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and the scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded category.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of the calculations required in a bias audit, including selection rate, impact ratio, intersectional categories, group classification, and unknown categories. It also correctly states that an independent auditor can exclude a category if it represents less than 2% of the data, which aligns with the ground truth.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly addresses the calculations required in a bias audit and includes the exclusion criteria for categories, but it introduces some additional details that, while relevant, are not necessary for a complete answer.

agent_answer:
The relationship between the definition of test data and when an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit that uses test data is as follows:

According to the provided information, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. Test data refers to data that is generated and obtained specifically for the purpose of conducting the bias audit.

In other words, if an employer or employment agency does not have enough historical data from their own use of the automated employment decision tool (AEDT) to conduct a meaningful bias audit, they can use test data instead. The summary of results of the bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was generated and obtained.

So, the definition of test data is relevant in determining when an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit that uses test data, which is when there is a lack of sufficient historical data for a statistically significant bias audit.

question: What is the relationship between the calculations in a bias audit of an AEDT and the requirements for the published results, and how do they differ?
reference_answer: In a bias audit of an AEDT, calculations are performed to determine the selection rates for each race/ethnicity and sex category, which are then compared to calculate an impact ratio. On the other hand, the requirements for the published results of a bias audit involve providing notices to employees and candidates for employment, as well as clarifying other obligations for the employer or employment agency. While the calculations focus on analyzing the impact of bias, the requirements for publishing the results are concerned with ensuring transparency and compliance with legal obligations.

(1) Calculate the median score for the full sample of applicants;

(3) Calculate the impact ratio for each category;  
(4) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision

(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
(d) Notwithstanding the requirements of paragraphs (2) and (3) of subdivision (b) and paragraphs (3) and 
(4) of subdivision (c), an independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of 
the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. Where such a 
category is excluded, the summary of results must include the independent auditor’s justification for the 
exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded 
category.  
 
Example: An employer uses an AEDT to score applicants for “culture fit.” To do so, the employer must 
ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than a year before the use of the AEDT.

§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

Document 5: These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law. 
 
Specifically, these new rules will: 
 
Define terms; 
 
Clarify the requirements for a bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for the published results of the required bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for notices that employers and employment agencies must provide to employees 
and candidates for employment; and  
 
Clarify other obligations for the employer or employment agency.  
 
The Department initially proposed a version of these rules in September 2022. The Department received 
comments from the public, including from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and 
advocacy organizations. Various issues raised in the comments led to a second version of the proposed rules, 
published in December 2022. Those changes included:  
 
Modifying the definition of AEDT to ensure greater focus; 
 
Clarifying that an “independent auditor” may not be employed or have a financial interest in an employer 
or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to use an AEDT or in a vendor that developed or 
distributed the AEDT; 
 
Revising the required calculation to be performed where an AEDT scores candidates;
metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'seed_document_id': 14, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What must be calculated in a bias audit of an AEDT?', 'answer': 'A bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category and compare the selection rates to determine an impact ratio.'}, {'question': 'What are the requirements for the published results of a bias audit?', 'answer': 'The requirements for the published results of a bias audit include providing notices to employees and candidates for employment and clarifying other obligations for the employer or employment agency.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The calculations in a bias audit of an AEDT are used to assess the impact of the AEDT on different categories of candidates, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. These calculations include determining the selection rate, impact ratio, and scoring rate for each category. The purpose of these calculations is to identify any potential biases or disparities in the AEDT's outcomes for different groups.

On the other hand, the requirements for the published results of a bias audit specify what information must be included in the summary of results. These requirements include providing the calculations for each category, indicating the number of individuals in unknown categories, and justifying any exclusion of categories that represent less than 2% of the data. The published results must also include information on whether historical data or test data was used for the bias audit, and if test data was used, an explanation of why historical data was not available.

In summary, the calculations in a bias audit are used to assess the impact of an AEDT, while the requirements for the published results dictate what information must be included in the summary of results to ensure transparency and accountability.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer correctly describes the calculations involved in a bias audit of an AEDT but does not accurately address the requirements for the published results. The ground truth specifies that the requirements for published results involve providing notices to employees and candidates, and clarifying other obligations for the employer or employment agency, which the agent's answer does not mention.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly addresses the components of the user query regarding the calculations and requirements in a bias audit of an AEDT, but it includes some minor inaccuracies and lacks clarity on the differences between the two aspects.

question: What are the requirements and penalties associated with using an automated employment decision tool?
reference_answer: An automated employment decision tool refers to a computational process that simplifies decision making in employment by providing scores, classifications, or recommendations. Violating the requirements for such tools can result in civil penalties, with the first violation carrying a maximum penalty of $500, and subsequent violations ranging from $500 to $1,500 per violation.

audit shall include but not be limited to the testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the
tool’s disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of
the code of federal regulations.
Employment decision. The term “employment decision” means to screen candidates for employment or
employees for promotion within the city.
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools. a. In the city, it shall be unlawful for
an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
1. Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of
such tool; and
2. A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of
the tool to which such audit applies has been made publicly available on the website of the employer or
employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
b. Notices required. In the city, any employer or employment agency that uses an automated
employment decision tool to screen an employee or a candidate who has applied for a position for an
employment decision shall notify each such employee or candidate who resides in the city of the following:
1. That an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with the assessment or
evaluation of such employee or candidate that resides in the city. Such notice shall be made no less than ten
business days before such use and allow a candidate to request an alternative selection process or
accommodation;
