§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required. In the city, any employer or employment agency that uses an automated employment decision tool to screen an employee or a
candidate who has applied for a position for an employment decision shall notify each such employee or candidate who resides in the city of the
following:
      1.   That an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with the assessment or evaluation of such employee or candidate that
resides in the city. Such notice shall be made no less than ten business days before such use and allow a candidate to request an alternative selection
process or accommodation;
      2.   The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

Document 2: The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-873 Enforcement.
The corporation counsel or such other persons designated by the corporation counsel on behalf of the department may initiate in any court of competent
jurisdiction any action or proceeding that may be appropriate or necessary for correction of any violation issued pursuant this subchapter, including
mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.
(L.L.
metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'seed_document_id': 24, 'topic': 'Enforcement and Penalties', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What is an automated employment decision tool?', 'answer': "The term 'automated employment decision tool' means any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons."}, {'question': 'What penalties are there for violating the requirements for automated employment decision tools?', 'answer': 'Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500 for each subsequent violation.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The requirements for using an automated employment decision tool are as follows:

1. The tool must have undergone a bias audit conducted within the past year before its use.
2. A summary of the most recent bias audit results, along with the distribution date of the tool, must be publicly available on the employer or employment agency's website before using the tool.
3. Employers or employment agencies must provide notice to employees or candidates residing in the city that an automated employment decision tool will be used in their assessment or evaluation. This notice must be given at least ten business days before the tool's use and should allow candidates to request an alternative selection process or accommodation.
4. Employers or employment agencies must also provide notice of the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in assessing the candidate or employee. This notice should be given at least ten business days before the tool's use.
5. If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the tool, the source of such data, and the data retention policy must be available upon written request by a candidate or employee. This information should be provided within 30 days of the written request, except where disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

As for penalties, the context does not explicitly mention them. However, it is common for violations of such requirements to result in fines or other legal consequences. The specific penalties associated with using an automated employment decision tool without meeting the requirements may be outlined in other relevant laws or regulations.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides detailed requirements for using an automated employment decision tool but does not address the penalties associated with violating these requirements. The ground truth specifies that violations can result in civil penalties, with specific amounts for first and subsequent violations.
reason_method2: The generated answer provides detailed requirements for using an automated employment decision tool but lacks specific information about penalties, which affects its completeness.

agent_answer:
The relationship between an automated employment decision tool and the requirements for using it is that the tool must meet certain criteria in order to be used for screening candidates or employees for employment decisions. The requirements are outlined in Section 20-871 of the New York City Council's regulations.

According to the regulations, it is unlawful for an employer or employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool unless it has been subject to a bias audit conducted within the past year. The results of the most recent bias audit must be publicly available on the employer or employment agency's website before the tool is used.

Additionally, employers or employment agencies must provide notices to candidates or employees who reside in the city and will be subject to the tool's assessment or evaluation. These notices must include information about the use of the tool, the job qualifications and characteristics it will assess, and information about the type of data collected, its source, and the data retention policy.

These requirements aim to ensure transparency and accountability in the use of automated employment decision tools. By conducting bias audits and providing information to candidates and employees, the regulations seek to mitigate potential biases and ensure that the tools are used fairly and responsibly in making employment decisions.

question: What are the requirements for an employer or employment agency to comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, and how do they compare to the information that must be made publicly available before the use of an AEDT?
reference_answer: To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must provide notice to candidates for employment through various means such as their website, job postings, or mail/email. On the other hand, before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency must make publicly available on their website the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT, a summary of the results, and the distribution date of the AEDT. While both requirements involve making information available on the employment section of the website, the first focuses on notice to candidates for employment, while the second focuses on information related to the AEDT and bias audit results.

agent_answer:
To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must provide notice to candidates for employment and employees being considered for promotion at least 10 business days before the use of an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT). The notice can be provided in the following ways:

For candidates for employment:
1. Notice on the employment section of the employer or employment agency's website in a clear and conspicuous manner.
2. Notice in a job posting.
3. Notice via U.S. mail or email.

For employees being considered for promotion:
1. Notice in a written policy or procedure provided to employees at least 10 business days before the use of an AEDT.
2. Notice in a job posting.
3. Notice via U.S. mail or email.

On the other hand, the information that must be made publicly available before the use of an AEDT includes:

1. The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, including the source and explanation of the data used for the bias audit, the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT falling within an unknown category, and the number of applicants or candidates, selection or scoring rates, and impact ratios for all categories.
2. The distribution date of the AEDT.

These requirements ensure that candidates and employees are informed about the use of AEDTs and have the opportunity to request alternative selection processes or reasonable accommodations. The publicly available information provides transparency regarding the bias audit results and distribution date of the AEDT.

question: What are the differences and similarities between the definitions of 'Scoring Rate' and 'Screen', and how do they relate to each other?
reference_answer: 'Scoring Rate' refers to the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above the sample’s median score, calculated by an AEDT. On the other hand, 'Screen' means making a determination about whether a candidate for employment or employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion process. While both concepts involve making assessments, 'Scoring Rate' focuses on evaluating scores based on a median, while 'Screen' involves evaluating candidates for selection or promotion. They are related in the sense that both involve making judgments or decisions based on certain criteria, but they differ in terms of the specific context and method of assessment.
reference_context:
Document 10: Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example. If 100 Hispanic women apply for a position and 40 are selected for an interview after use of an 
AEDT, the selection rate for Hispanic women is 40/100 or 40%.  
 
Simplified output. “Simplified output” means a prediction or classification as specified in the definition 
for “machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence.” A simplified output 
may take the form of a score (e.g., rating a candidate’s estimated technical skills), tag or categorization 
(e.g., categorizing a candidate’s resume based on key words, assigning a skill or trait to a candidate), 
recommendation (e.g., whether a candidate should be given an interview), or ranking (e.g., arranging a 
list of candidates based on how well their cover letters match the job description). It does not refer to the 
output from analytical tools that translate or transcribe existing text, e.g., convert a resume from a PDF 
or transcribe a video or audio interview.

rate of the most selected category or (2) the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the 
highest scoring category.

metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'seed_document_id': 10, 'topic': 'Definitions', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': "What is the definition of 'Scoring Rate'?", 'answer': "'Scoring Rate' means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT."}, {'question': "What does 'Screen' mean?", 'answer': "'Screen' means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion process."}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The definitions of "Scoring Rate" and "Screen" are related to each other in the context of automated employment decision tools (AEDTs) and the hiring or promotion process. 

1. Scoring Rate: "Scoring Rate" refers to the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above the sample's median score, as calculated by an AEDT. It measures how well individuals in a particular category perform in relation to the overall sample. For example, if an AEDT assigns scores to candidates based on their technical skills, the scoring rate for a category would indicate the percentage of individuals in that category who receive a score above the median score.

2. Screen: "Screen" means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or an employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion process. It involves evaluating the qualifications, skills, and other relevant factors of a candidate or employee to decide whether they should move forward in the selection process. AEDTs can be used to assist in the screening process by providing information or recommendations about candidates based on their scores or other criteria.

In summary, the scoring rate is a measure of performance within a specific category based on the scores generated by an AEDT, while screening is the process of evaluating candidates or employees to make decisions about their advancement in the hiring or promotion process. AEDTs can provide scoring information that can be used in the screening process to help determine which candidates should be selected or advanced.

question: What is the relationship between the definition of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' and the requirement for using such a tool in the city?
reference_answer: The definition of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' refers to a computational process that assists or replaces discretionary decision making in employment decisions. In the city, it is unlawful to use such a tool to screen candidates or employees unless it has undergone a bias audit within the past year. The requirement ensures that the use of these tools is regulated and monitored for fairness and non-discrimination.

Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code. 
 
Employment Agency. “Employment agency” means “Employment agency” as defined by 6 RCNY § 5-
249.  
 
Historical data.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)

      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)

mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.

question: What is the relationship between the requirements for a bias audit and the concept of test data?
reference_answer: The requirements for a bias audit involve calculating selection rates for different demographic categories to determine an impact ratio. Test data, on the other hand, refers to the data used in a bias audit that is not historical data. Test data is necessary to conduct a bias audit and apply the requirements. In summary, the requirements for a bias audit rely on analyzing selection rates, while test data is the specific type of data used to perform the audit.

Document 5: These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law. 
 
Specifically, these new rules will: 
 
Define terms; 
 
Clarify the requirements for a bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for the published results of the required bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for notices that employers and employment agencies must provide to employees 
and candidates for employment; and  
 
Clarify other obligations for the employer or employment agency.  
 
The Department initially proposed a version of these rules in September 2022. The Department received 
comments from the public, including from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and 
advocacy organizations. Various issues raised in the comments led to a second version of the proposed rules, 
published in December 2022. Those changes included:  
 
Modifying the definition of AEDT to ensure greater focus; 
 
Clarifying that an “independent auditor” may not be employed or have a financial interest in an employer 
or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to use an AEDT or in a vendor that developed or 
distributed the AEDT; 
 
Revising the required calculation to be performed where an AEDT scores candidates;

race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories; 
 
Clarifying the types of data that may be used to conduct a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying that multiple employers using the same AEDT may rely on the same bias audit so long as they 
provide historical data, if available, for the independent auditor to consider in such bias audit; and 
 
Clarifying that an AEDT may not be used if its most recent bias audit is more than a year old; 
 
The Department received comments about the second version of the proposed rule from the public, including 
from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and advocacy organizations. Various 
issues raised in the comments resulted in changes that are present in these final rules. These changes include: 
 
Modifying the definition of “machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence” 
to expand its scope; 
 
Adding a requirement that the bias audit indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are 
not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category, and requiring that number 
be included in the summary of results; 
 
Allowing an independent auditor to exclude a category that comprises less than 2% of the data being 
used for the bias audit from the calculations of impact ratio; 
 
Clarifying the examples of a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted using the 
historical data of other employers or employment agencies; 
 
Providing examples of when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted with 
historical data, test data, or historical data from other employers and employment agencies; 
 
Clarifying that the number of applicants in a category and scoring rate of a category, if applicable, must 
be included in the summary of results. 
 
New material is underlined. 
[Deleted material is in brackets.] 
 
“Shall” and “must” denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this 
department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

Document 15: 7 
 
(3) Calculate the impact ratio for each category;  
(4) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision 
separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (i.e., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates); and  
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
(d) Notwithstanding the requirements of paragraphs (2) and (3) of subdivision (b) and paragraphs (3) and 
(4) of subdivision (c), an independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of 
the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. Where such a 
category is excluded, the summary of results must include the independent auditor’s justification for the 
exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded 
category.  
 
Example: An employer uses an AEDT to score applicants for “culture fit.” To do so, the employer must 
ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than a year before the use of the AEDT.
metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'seed_document_id': 5, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What are the requirements for a bias audit?', 'answer': 'A bias audit must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category and compare the selection rates to determine an impact ratio.'}, {'question': 'What is test data in the context of a bias audit?', 'answer': 'Test data is data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
The requirements for a bias audit and the concept of test data are related in the context of conducting a bias audit for an automated employment decision tool (AEDT). 

According to the provided information, a bias audit must use historical data of the AEDT. This means that the audit should analyze the past performance and outcomes of the AEDT to assess any potential bias or disparate impact on different groups of individuals. The historical data used for the audit can come from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the AEDT.

However, there are circumstances where an employer or employment agency can rely on a bias audit that uses test data instead of historical data. This is allowed if there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. In such cases, the employer or employment agency can use test data to assess the bias of the AEDT.

If a bias audit uses test data, the summary of the audit results must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was generated and obtained. This ensures transparency and provides an explanation for the use of test data instead of historical data.

In summary, while the default requirement for a bias audit is to use historical data, the concept of test data can be utilized when there is a lack of sufficient historical data for a statistically significant audit.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of the relationship between bias audits and test data, but it does not directly address the core requirement of calculating selection rates for different demographic categories to determine an impact ratio. The ground truth emphasizes the importance of selection rates and impact ratios, which the agent's answer does not explicitly mention.
reason_method2: The generated answer partially addresses the relationship between bias audits and test data but contains inaccuracies regarding the necessity of historical data and does not fully align with the reference answer's emphasis on selection rates.

question: What is the relationship between the purpose of a bias audit and when an employer can rely on a bias audit that uses test data?
reference_answer: The purpose of a bias audit is to calculate the impact ratio for each category and ensure non-discriminatory impact. An employer can rely on a bias audit that uses test data when there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. In other words, the purpose of the bias audit informs the circumstances in which an employer can use test data for the audit.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

agent_answer:
The purpose of a bias audit is to assess the impact of an Artificial Intelligence Employment Decision Tool (AEDT) on different categories of candidates, such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. It is conducted to identify any potential biases in the AEDT's selection or scoring process.

An employer can rely on a bias audit that uses test data when there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. This means that if the employer does not have enough data from its own use of the AEDT or if the historical data provided by other employers or employment agencies is not enough, they can use test data for the bias audit.

However, it is important for the employer to explain in the summary of results why historical data was not used and how the test data used was generated and obtained. This ensures transparency and accountability in the bias audit process.

question: What are the definitions of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' and 'Bias Audit', and how are they related according to § 20-870 of the Code?
reference_answer: 'Automated employment decision tool' refers to an automated tool used for making employment decisions, as defined by § 20-870 of the Code. Similarly, 'bias audit' refers to a specific type of audit conducted to assess bias, also defined by § 20-870 of the Code. Both terms are defined within the same section of the Code, indicating a relationship between the concepts in the context of employment decision-making and bias assessment.

Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code.

agent_answer:
According to § 20-870 of the Code, the definitions of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' and 'Bias Audit' are as follows:

1. Automated Employment Decision Tool: It refers to any computational process that is derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence. This tool issues simplified output, such as a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making for making employment decisions that impact individuals. However, it does not include tools that do not automate or support discretionary decision-making processes and do not materially impact individuals.

2. Bias Audit: It refers to an impartial evaluation conducted by an independent auditor. The bias audit involves testing an automated employment decision tool to assess its disparate impact on individuals of any component category required to be reported by employers under federal regulations.

According to § 20-870 of the Code, a bias audit is a specific type of evaluation that is performed on an automated employment decision tool to assess its potential bias or disparate impact on individuals. It is conducted by an independent auditor to ensure objectivity and impartiality. The purpose of the bias audit is to evaluate the tool's impact on individuals of different categories and determine if there are any discriminatory effects.

§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,

testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of

(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-873 Enforcement.
The corporation counsel or such other persons designated by the corporation counsel on behalf of the department may initiate in any court of competent
jurisdiction any action or proceeding that may be appropriate or necessary for correction of any violation issued pursuant this subchapter, including
mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.

agent_answer:
The requirements and penalties associated with the use of automated employment decision tools are outlined in the New York City Council's legislation. Here is a summary:

Requirements:
1. Bias Audit: Before using an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision, the tool must undergo a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to its use.
2. Public Availability: A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit, along with the distribution date of the tool, must be made publicly available on the employer or employment agency's website before using the tool.
3. Notice to Employees/Candidates: Employers or employment agencies using automated employment decision tools must notify each employee or candidate residing in the city of the following:
   a. The use of an automated employment decision tool in the assessment or evaluation process.
   b. The job qualifications and characteristics that the tool will use in the assessment.
   c. Information about the type of data collected, the source of the data, and the data retention policy (if not disclosed on the website). This information must be provided upon written request within 30 days.

Penalties:
The legislation does not explicitly mention penalties for non-compliance with the requirements. However, it is common for violations of city ordinances to result in fines or other enforcement actions. The specific penalties for non-compliance with the requirements of this legislation would likely be determined by the relevant enforcement agency or authority.

reason_method2: The generated answer correctly addresses the requirements associated with automated employment decision tools and provides relevant details, but it lacks specific information about penalties, which affects its completeness.

question: What are the requirements for an employer or employment agency to provide information about the use of an AEDT on their website, and how can they notify candidates about it?
reference_answer: An employer or employment agency must provide the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results on their website. Additionally, they can notify candidates about the use of an AEDT by providing notice on the employment section of their website.

§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.  
(b) The requirements of subdivision (a) of this section may be met with an active hyperlink to a website 
containing the required summary of results and distribution date, provided that the link is clearly identified 
as a link to results of the bias audit. 
(c) An employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for 
at least 6 months after its latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.   
 
§ 5-304 Notice to Candidates and Employees.  
(a) The notice required by § 20-871(b)(1) of the Code must include instructions for how an individual can 
request an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation under other laws, if 
available. Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT.
metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'seed_document_id': 22, 'topic': 'Requirements', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What information must an employer or employment agency provide on their website before the use of an AEDT?', 'answer': 'The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results.'}, {'question': 'How can an employer or employment agency provide notice to a candidate for employment about the use of an AEDT?', 'answer': 'They can provide notice on the employment section of their website.'}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
According to § 5-303(a) of the administrative code, an employer or employment agency in New York City must make the following information publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:

1. The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. This summary should include the source and explanation of the data used for the bias audit, the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT falling within an unknown category, and the number of applicants or candidates, selection or scoring rates, and impact ratios for all categories.

2. The distribution date of the AEDT.

The requirements of § 5-303(a) can also be met by providing an active hyperlink to a website containing the required summary of results and distribution date, as long as the link is clearly identified as a link to the results of the bias audit.

Additionally, § 5-303(c) states that the employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for at least 6 months after the latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.

To notify candidates about the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency can do any of the following, as per § 5-304(b):

1. Provide notice on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner at least 10 business days before using an AEDT.

2. Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before using an AEDT.

3. Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or email at least 10 business days before using an AEDT.

It's important to note that these requirements are specific to New York City and may not apply to other locations.

reason_method2: The generated answer comprehensively addresses all components of the user query with accurate and detailed information, aligning closely with the reference answer.

While both requirements aim to ensure transparency and fairness in the use of AEDTs, the information on the website provides ongoing information to the public, while the notice requirement specifically applies to candidates for employment.

§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required. In the city, any employer or employment agency that uses an automated employment decision tool to screen an employee or a
candidate who has applied for a position for an employment decision shall notify each such employee or candidate who resides in the city of the
following:
      1.   That an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with the assessment or evaluation of such employee or candidate that
resides in the city. Such notice shall be made no less than ten business days before such use and allow a candidate to request an alternative selection
process or accommodation;
      2.   The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

Document 7: 3 
 
Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code. 
 
Employment Agency. “Employment agency” means “Employment agency” as defined by 6 RCNY § 5-
249.  
 
Historical data.

agent_answer:
In order for an employer in the city of New York to use an automated employment decision tool to screen candidates for a job position, the following requirements must be met:

1. The tool must have been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to its use.
2. A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit, as well as the distribution date of the tool to which the audit applies, must be made publicly available on the employer's website before the tool is used.

Additionally, the employer must provide the following notices to employees or job candidates:

1. A notice that an automated employment decision tool will be used in the assessment or evaluation of the employee or candidate. This notice must be provided at least ten business days before the tool is used and must allow the candidate to request an alternative selection process or accommodation.
2. A notice of the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of the candidate or employee. This notice must also be provided at least ten business days before the tool is used.
3. If the information about the type of data collected for the tool, the source of such data, and the employer's data retention policy is not disclosed on the employer's website, it must be made available upon written request by a candidate or employee. This information must be provided within 30 days of the written request, unless its disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer includes additional details about notices to employees or job candidates that are not mentioned in the ground truth. While these details may be accurate, they go beyond the requirements specified in the ground truth answer.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly addresses the main requirements for using an automated employment decision tool in New York, including the bias audit and public notice, but adds additional details that, while accurate, are not part of the reference answer.

question: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. Can the employer rely on a bias audit conducted using test data?
reference_answer: No, the employer cannot rely on a bias audit conducted using test data. According to § 5-303, an employer may rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other employers or employment agencies, but not on a bias audit conducted using test data.
reference_context:
Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit. The vendor provides historical data regarding 
applicant selection that the vendor has collected from multiple employers to an independent auditor who

Example 2: An employment agency has been using an AEDT for 6 months. The bias audit the 
employment agency relied on before its first use of the AEDT was conducted 10 months ago using test 
data. The employment agency will need an updated bias audit if it will continue to use the AEDT once 12 
months have passed since the bias audit it first relied on was conducted. The employment agency’s data 
from 6 months of use of the AEDT is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias 
audit. The employment agency may rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other employers and 
employment agencies if it provides its 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for use and 
consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

However, they cannot rely on a bias audit conducted using test data.

question: If an employer in New York City uses an automated employment decision tool to screen candidates for a promotion within the city, what information must be disclosed to the candidates?
reference_answer: If an employer in New York City uses an automated employment decision tool to screen candidates for a promotion within the city, they must disclose the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of the candidates. This information must be disclosed no less than 10 business days before the use of the tool.
reference_context:
Document 2: The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-873 Enforcement.
The corporation counsel or such other persons designated by the corporation counsel on behalf of the department may initiate in any court of competent
jurisdiction any action or proceeding that may be appropriate or necessary for correction of any violation issued pursuant this subchapter, including
mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.

agent_answer:
According to the rules outlined in Subchapter T of Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York, if an employer in New York City uses an automated employment decision tool to screen candidates for a promotion, the following information must be disclosed to the candidates:

1. The fact that an automated employment decision tool will be used in the assessment or evaluation of the candidate. This notice must be provided no less than ten business days before the use of the tool and should allow the candidate to request an alternative selection process or accommodation.

2. The job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of the candidate. This notice must also be provided no less than ten business days before the use of the tool.

3. If the information about the type of data collected for the automated employment decision tool, the source of such data, and the employer's data retention policy is not disclosed on the employer's website, it must be made available upon written request by the candidate. The employer must provide this information within 30 days of the written request, unless the disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

It is important to note that these requirements are specific to New York City and may not apply in other jurisdictions.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer includes additional details that are not required by the ground truth. The ground truth specifies only the disclosure of job qualifications and characteristics used by the tool, and that this must be done no less than 10 business days before use. The agent's answer adds information about alternative selection processes, data collection, and data retention policies, which are not mentioned in the ground truth.
reason_method2: The generated answer comprehensively addresses all components of the user query, providing accurate and detailed information about the disclosure requirements for automated employment decision tools in New York City.

question: If an employer or employment agency violates the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool, what penalties may they face?
reference_answer: An employer or employment agency that violates the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool may be liable for a civil penalty of not more than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation. For each subsequent violation, the penalty may be not less than $500 nor more than $1,500. Additionally, each day on which the tool is used in violation of the requirements gives rise to a separate violation. Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or employee in violation of the requirements also constitutes a separate violation.

metadata: {'question_type': 'rule_conclusion', 'seed_document_id': 25, 'topic': 'Enforcement and Penalties', 'distracting_context': None, 'situational_context': None, 'original_questions': None, 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
If an employer or employment agency violates the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool, they may face the following penalties:

1. Civil Penalty: For a first violation, they may be liable for a civil penalty of not more than $500. For each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, they may be liable for a civil penalty of not less than $500 nor more than $1,500.

2. Separate Violations: Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of the requirements gives rise to a separate violation.

3. Failure to Provide Notice: Failure to provide any required notice to a candidate or employee constitutes a separate violation.

4. Administrative Proceedings: A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by the subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

Therefore, if the employer does not have enough historical data to conduct a bias audit, they can use test data as long as they provide a valid justification for not using historical data.

question: An employer in the city wants to use an AEDT for employment decisions. How should the employer provide notice to candidates for employment who reside in the city?
reference_answer: To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, the employer may provide notice to candidates for employment who reside in the city by doing any of the following: (1) Providing notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT, (2) Providing notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT, or (3) Providing notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT.

question: If an employer or employment agency uses an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision in New York City, what notices are they required to provide?
reference_answer:
In New York City, the employer or employment agency that uses an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision must provide the following notices:
1. Notice that an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with the assessment or evaluation of the candidate or employee, at least ten business days before such use, allowing the candidate to request an alternative selection process or accommodation.
2. Notice of the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of the candidate or employee, at least 10 business days before such use.
3. If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment decision tool, the source of such data, and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a candidate or employee, provided within 30 days of the written request, unless such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

collected for the automated employment decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment
agency’s data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a candidate or employee.
Such
information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall
not be disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law
enforcement investigation.
§ 20-872 Penalties. a. Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated
pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more than $500 for a first violation and each
additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than
$1,500 for each subsequent violation.
b. Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall
give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a of section 20-871.
c. Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of
subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a separate violation.
d. A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal
established within the office of administrative trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to
conduct such proceedings.

agent_answer:
If an employer or employment agency uses an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision in New York City, they are required to provide the following notices:

1. Notice of Use: They must notify each employee or candidate who resides in the city that an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with their assessment or evaluation. This notice must be provided no less than ten business days before the use of the tool and should allow the candidate to request an alternative selection process or accommodation if available.

2. Notice of Job Qualifications and Characteristics: They must also provide notice of the job qualifications and characteristics that the automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of the candidate or employee. This notice must be provided no less than ten business days before the use of the tool.

3. Data Information: If the information about the type of data collected for the automated employment decision tool, the source of such data, and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy is not disclosed on their website, they must make this information available upon written request by a candidate or employee. The requested information must be provided within 30 days of the written request, unless its disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

These notices aim to ensure transparency and provide candidates and employees with information about the use of automated employment decision tools in their assessment or evaluation.

It includes the notice of use, notice of job qualifications and characteristics, and information about data collection, source, and retention policy, aligning with the ground truth.

question: An employer uses an AEDT to score applicants for 'culture fit.' The AEDT conducted a bias audit that excluded a category representing less than 2% of the data used. Is this exclusion allowed under the law?
reference_answer: No, the exclusion of a category that represents less than 2% of the data used for the bias audit is not allowed under the law. The law requires that all categories be included in the calculations for impact ratio, regardless of their representation in the data.
